retain control. Based on these insights, we provide design recommendations for
more accessible and inclusive AI-assisted tools.

AI.tldr: A longitudinal study with screen reader users reveals their experiences with AI code assistants like GitHub Copilot, highlighting benefits and areas for improvement in accessibility and user control.
AI.motivation: To understand how screen reader users engage with generative AI assistants in programming, as existing research is limited.
AI.method: Conducted a longitudinal study involving 16 screen reader users who interacted with GitHub Copilot through tutorials and programming tasks, providing initial and follow-up feedback.
AI.result: Participants found AI code assistants enhanced their programming capabilities and bridged accessibility gaps, but faced challenges in managing outputs and learning advanced tools.
AI.conclusion: The study identifies both the benefits of AI-assisted programming for screen reader users and the need for improved design to enhance accessibility, user intent communication, and control.
key_contributions: Insights into the experiences of screen reader users with AI code assistants
Identification of barriers and areas needing improvement in AI-assisted programming tools
Design recommendations for creating more inclusive AI tools
AI.limitations: Limited to 16 participants; further research needed to validate findings across diverse user groups.

title: Infini-gram mini: Exact n-gram Search at the Internet Scale with FM-Index
summary:
Language models are trained mainly on massive text data from the Internet,
and it becomes increasingly important to understand this data source.
Exact-match search engines enable searching in large text corpora -- counting
string appearances and retrieving the enclosing documents -- yet the high
storage overhead hinders their application on Internet-scale data. We present
Infini-gram mini, an efficient and scalable system that can make petabyte-level
text corpora searchable. Based on the FM-index data structure (Ferragina and
Manzini, 2000), which simultaneously indexes and compresses text, our system
creates indexes with size only 44% of the corpus. Infini-gram mini greatly
improves upon the best existing implementation of FM-index in terms of indexing
speed (18$\times$) and memory use during both indexing (3.2$\times$ reduction)
and querying (down to a negligible amount). We index 46TB of Internet text in
50 days with a single 128-core CPU node (or 19 hours if using 75 such nodes).
We show one important use case of Infini-gram mini in a large-scale analysis of
benchmark contamination. We find several core LM evaluation benchmarks to be
heavily contaminated in Internet crawls (up to 40% in SQuAD), which could lead
to overestimating the capabilities of language models if trained on such data.
We host a benchmark contamination bulletin to share the contamination rate of
many core and community-contributed benchmarks. We also release a web interface
and an API endpoint to serve general search queries on Infini-gram mini
indexes.

AI.tldr: Infini-gram mini is a scalable system that makes petabyte-level text corpora searchable, improving storage efficiency and indexing speed for large text data.
AI.motivation: Understanding the massive text data sources that language models are trained on is crucial, especially as the storage overhead hinders the use of exact-match search engines on large internet-scale datasets.
AI.method: The system is based on the FM-index data structure, which indexes and compresses text simultaneously, achieving an index size of only 44% of the original text corpus.
AI.result: Infini-gram mini achieves an 18x improvement in indexing speed and reduces memory use during indexing by 3.2 times. It can index 46TB of text in 50 days with one CPU node (or in 19 hours with 75 nodes).
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the risks of benchmark contamination in LM evaluations, revealing contamination rates of up to 40% in core benchmarks, which could mislead trust in language model capabilities. Additionally, tools are released to help track and query these indexes.
key_contributions: Introduction of Infini-gram mini, a scalable system for text corpus indexing
Demonstration of benchmark contamination in language model evaluation
Release of a web interface and API for general search queries
AI.limitations: The paper focuses on indexing efficiency and benchmark contamination without providing a detailed analysis of the effects of such contamination on language model performance.

title: Enhancing Orthopedic Surgical Training With Interactive Photorealistic 3D Visualization
summary:
Surgical training integrates several years of didactic learning, simulation,
mentorship, and hands-on experience. Challenges include stress, technical
demands, and new technologies. Orthopedic education often uses static materials
like books, images, and videos, lacking interactivity. This study compares a
new interactive photorealistic 3D visualization to 2D videos for learning total
hip arthroplasty. In a randomized controlled trial, participants (students and
residents) were evaluated on spatial awareness, tool placement, and task times
in a simulation. Results show that interactive photorealistic 3D visualization
significantly improved scores, with residents and those with prior 3D
experience performing better. These results emphasize the potential of the
interactive photorealistic 3D visualization to enhance orthopedic training.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates the effectiveness of interactive photorealistic 3D visualization compared to 2D videos for learning total hip arthroplasty, showing significant improvements in participant performance.
AI.motivation: The challenges of surgical training include stress and the limitations of static learning materials that lack interactivity.
AI.method: A randomized controlled trial was conducted where students and residents were assessed on their spatial awareness, tool placement, and task times while learning total hip arthroplasty using 3D visualization versus 2D videos.
AI.result: Participants using interactive photorealistic 3D visualization showed significantly improved scores, particularly among residents and those with prior 3D experience.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the beneficial impact of interactive photorealistic 3D visualization in enhancing orthopedic surgical training.
key_contributions: Introduction of interactive photorealistic 3D visualization in surgical training
Demonstration of improved learning outcomes in total hip arthroplasty
Comparison with traditional 2D video learning methods

title: Large Language Models for History, Philosophy, and Sociology of Science: Interpretive Uses, Methodological Challenges, and Critical Perspectives
summary:
This paper explores the use of large language models (LLMs) as research tools
in the history, philosophy, and sociology of science (HPSS). LLMs are
remarkably effective at processing unstructured text and inferring meaning from
context, offering new affordances that challenge long-standing divides between
computational and interpretive methods. This raises both opportunities and
challenges for HPSS, which emphasizes interpretive methodologies and
understands meaning as context-dependent, ambiguous, and historically situated.
We argue that HPSS is uniquely positioned not only to benefit from LLMs'
capabilities but also to interrogate their epistemic assumptions and
infrastructural implications. To this end, we first offer a concise primer on
LLM architectures and training paradigms tailored to non-technical readers. We
frame LLMs not as neutral tools but as epistemic infrastructures that encode
assumptions about meaning, context, and similarity, conditioned by their
training data, architecture, and patterns of use. We then examine how
computational techniques enhanced by LLMs, such as structuring data, detecting
patterns, and modeling dynamic processes, can be applied to support
interpretive research in HPSS. Our analysis compares full-context and
generative models, outlines strategies for domain and task adaptation (e.g.,
continued pretraining, fine-tuning, and retrieval-augmented generation), and
evaluates their respective strengths and limitations for interpretive inquiry
in HPSS. We conclude with four lessons for integrating LLMs into HPSS: (1)
model selection involves interpretive trade-offs; (2) LLM literacy is
foundational; (3) HPSS must define its own benchmarks and corpora; and (4) LLMs
should enhance, not replace, interpretive methods.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the role of large language models (LLMs) in the history, philosophy, and sociology of science (HPSS), discussing their potential as research tools while addressing the epistemic assumptions they carry.
AI.motivation: To explore the integration of LLMs in HPSS and their implications for interpretive methodologies in science.
AI.method: The paper provides a primer on LLM architectures, compares computational techniques enhanced by LLMs for interpretive research, and outlines strategies like fine-tuning and retrieval-augmented generation.
AI.result: LLMs are found to offer substantial opportunities for data structuring, pattern detection, and modeling processes but also carry epistemic assumptions that need to be critically examined.
AI.conclusion: Integration of LLMs in HPSS requires careful consideration of interpretive trade-offs, developing LLM literacy, defining domain-specific benchmarks, and enhancing (not replacing) interpretive methods.
key_contributions: Offer a primer on LLMs tailored to non-technical readers
Examine computational techniques for interpretive research
Propose strategies for domain adaptation of LLMs
AI.limitations: The focus is primarily on interpretive methodologies with less emphasis on technical algorithmic design.

title: The User Perspective on Island-Ready 6G Communication: A Survey of Future Smartphone Usage in Crisis-Struck Areas with Local Cellular Connectivity
comment:
22 pages, 6 figures, the dataset is available at
  https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14812894
summary:
Using smartphone apps during crises is well-established, proving critical for
efficient crisis response. However, such apps become futile without an Internet
connection, which is a common issue during crises. The ongoing 6G
standardization explores the capability to provide local cellular connectivity
for areas cut off from the Internet in crises. This paper introduces to the HCI
community the concept of cellular island connectivity in isolated areas,
promising a seamless transition from normal operation to island operation with
local-only cellular connectivity. It presents findings from a survey (N = 857)
among adult smartphone users from major German cities regarding their
smartphone usage preferences in this model. Results show a shift in app demand,
with users favoring general-purpose apps over dedicated crisis apps in specific
scenarios. We prioritize smartphone services based on their criticality,
distinguishing between apps essential for crisis response and those supporting
routines. Our findings provide operators, developers, and authorities insights
into making user-centric design decisions for implementing island-ready 6G
communication.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses the implications of smartphone app usage during crises, focusing on a proposed solution for providing local cellular connectivity through the 6G standard called cellular island connectivity. It presents survey findings on user preferences for apps in crisis scenarios.
AI.motivation: To explore how smartphone apps can remain functional during crises where Internet connectivity is lost, introducing the concept of cellular island connectivity.
AI.method: A survey was conducted with 857 adult smartphone users in major German cities to assess their preferences for smartphone apps in the context of local-only cellular connectivity during crises.
AI.result: The study found a shift in app usage preferences, with users favoring general-purpose apps over crisis-specific apps in certain situations. Critical services were prioritized based on their importance for crisis response and routine support.
AI.conclusion: The findings offer insights for operators, developers, and authorities to design user-centric applications ready for operation in crisis scenarios without Internet access.
key_contributions: Introduction of cellular island connectivity concept
Survey findings on app preferences during crises
Framework for prioritizing smartphone services in crisis situations

title: The Behavior Gap: Evaluating Zero-shot LLM Agents in Complex Task-Oriented Dialogs
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM)-based agents have significantly impacted
Task-Oriented Dialog Systems (TODS) but continue to face notable performance
challenges, especially in zero-shot scenarios. While prior work has noted this
performance gap, the behavioral factors driving the performance gap remain
under-explored. This study proposes a comprehensive evaluation framework to
quantify the behavior gap between AI agents and human experts, focusing on
discrepancies in dialog acts, tool usage, and knowledge utilization. Our
findings reveal that this behavior gap is a critical factor negatively
impacting the performance of LLM agents. Notably, as task complexity increases,
the behavior gap widens (correlation: 0.963), leading to a degradation of agent
performance on complex task-oriented dialogs. For the most complex task in our
study, even the GPT-4o-based agent exhibits low alignment with human behavior,
with low F1 scores for dialog acts (0.464), excessive and often misaligned tool
usage with a F1 score of 0.139, and ineffective usage of external knowledge.
Reducing such behavior gaps leads to significant performance improvement (24.3%
on average). This study highlights the importance of comprehensive behavioral
evaluations and improved alignment strategies to enhance the effectiveness of
LLM-based TODS in handling complex tasks.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates the performance gap between LLM agents and human experts in Task-Oriented Dialog Systems (TODS) and proposes an evaluation framework to analyze behavioral discrepancies that affect agent performance, especially in complex tasks.
AI.motivation: To address the under-explored behavioral factors driving the performance gap between LLM-based agents and human experts in TODS, particularly in zero-shot scenarios.
AI.method: A comprehensive evaluation framework was developed to quantify the behavior gap in terms of dialog acts, tool usage, and knowledge utilization, analyzing the correlation between task complexity and agent performance.
AI.result: The study found a strong correlation (0.963) between task complexity and the widening behavior gap, resulting in poor performance of LLM agents, with GPT-4o scoring low in F1 metrics for dialog acts (0.464) and tool usage (0.139).
AI.conclusion: Reducing behavioral gaps is crucial for improving the effectiveness of LLM-based TODS, with potential performance improvements of 24.3% when alignment strategies are implemented.
key_contributions: Development of a comprehensive evaluation framework for behavior gaps
Quantification of the impact of behavior gaps on LLM performance
Analysis of the correlation between task complexity and performance degradation
AI.limitations: The study primarily focuses on zero-shot scenarios and may not fully generalize to other contexts or training conditions.

title: From Flat to Feeling: A Feasibility and Impact Study on Dynamic Facial Emotions in AI-Generated Avatars
summary:
Dynamic facial emotion is essential for believable AI-generated avatars;
however, most systems remain visually inert, limiting their utility in
high-stakes simulations such as virtual training for investigative interviews
with abused children. We introduce and evaluate a real-time architecture fusing
Unreal Engine 5 MetaHuman rendering with NVIDIA Omniverse Audio2Face to
translate vocal prosody into high-fidelity facial expressions on photorealistic
child avatars. We implemented a distributed two-PC setup that decouples
language processing and speech synthesis from GPU-intensive rendering, designed
to support low-latency interaction in desktop and VR environments. A
between-subjects study ($N=70$) using audio+visual and visual-only conditions
assessed perceptual impacts as participants rated emotional clarity, facial
realism, and empathy for two avatars expressing joy, sadness, and anger.
  Results demonstrate that avatars could express emotions recognizably, with
sadness and joy achieving high identification rates. However, anger recognition
significantly dropped without audio, highlighting the importance of congruent
vocal cues for high-arousal emotions. Interestingly, removing audio boosted
perceived facial realism, suggesting that audiovisual desynchrony remains a key
design challenge. These findings confirm the technical feasibility of
generating emotionally expressive avatars and provide guidance for improving
non-verbal communication in sensitive training simulations.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a real-time architecture for creating emotionally expressive AI avatars using Unreal Engine 5 and NVIDIA Omniverse Audio2Face, demonstrating significant findings on emotion recognition in avatars and implications for training simulations.
AI.motivation: The need for believable AI-generated avatars in high-stakes simulations, such as virtual training for investigative interviews, to enhance emotional expression and realism.
AI.method: The study implemented a distributed two-PC setup that separates language processing and speech synthesis from GPU-intensive rendering, enabling low-latency interaction in desktop and VR settings. A between-subjects study with 70 participants evaluated emotional clarity, facial realism, and empathy in avatars expressing joy, sadness, and anger under audio+visual and visual-only conditions.
AI.result: The results indicated that avatars could express emotions like sadness and joy with high identification rates, but recognition of anger dropped significantly without audio. Interestingly, the absence of audio led to higher perceived facial realism.
AI.conclusion: The findings validate the technical feasibility of generating emotionally expressive avatars and highlight the critical balance necessary for effective non-verbal communication in sensitive training simulations.
key_contributions: Real-time architecture for fusing vocal prosody and facial expressions in AI avatars
Insights on the importance of audio cues in emotion recognition
Guidance for enhancing non-verbal communication in training simulations
AI.limitations: The study may not generalize across all types of emotional expressions or diverse avatar designs.

title: Med-U1: Incentivizing Unified Medical Reasoning in LLMs via Large-scale Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Medical Question-Answering (QA) encompasses a broad spectrum of tasks,
including multiple choice questions (MCQ), open-ended text generation, and
complex computational reasoning. Despite this variety, a unified framework for
delivering high-quality medical QA has yet to emerge. Although recent progress
in reasoning-augmented large language models (LLMs) has shown promise, their
ability to achieve comprehensive medical understanding is still largely
unexplored. In this paper, we present Med-U1, a unified framework for robust
reasoning across medical QA tasks with diverse output formats, ranging from
MCQs to complex generation and computation tasks. Med-U1 employs pure
large-scale reinforcement learning with mixed rule-based binary reward
functions, incorporating a length penalty to manage output verbosity. With
multi-objective reward optimization, Med-U1 directs LLMs to produce concise and
verifiable reasoning chains. Empirical results reveal that Med-U1 significantly
improves performance across multiple challenging Med-QA benchmarks, surpassing
even larger specialized and proprietary models. Furthermore, Med-U1
demonstrates robust generalization to out-of-distribution (OOD) tasks.
Extensive analysis presents insights into training strategies, reasoning chain
length control, and reward design for medical LLMs. The code will be released.

AI.tldr: Med-U1 is a unified framework for improving medical question-answering (QA) using reasoning-augmented large language models (LLMs), showing significant performance gains across various tasks.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the lack of a unified framework for high-quality medical QA despite the growth in reasoning capabilities of LLMs.
AI.method: Med-U1 uses large-scale reinforcement learning with mixed rule-based binary reward functions, incorporating multi-objective reward optimization to enhance LLM outputs in medical QA tasks.
AI.result: Med-U1 improves performance on challenging Med-QA benchmarks and shows robust generalization to out-of-distribution tasks.
AI.conclusion: Med-U1 provides valuable insights for training medical LLMs, particularly regarding reward design and reasoning chain control, with the code to be released for further research.
key_contributions: Introduction of Med-U1 as a unified framework
Implementation of mixed rule-based reinforcement learning
Demonstration of significant performance improvements on Med-QA benchmarks

title: Can you see how I learn? Human observers' inferences about Reinforcement Learning agents' learning processes
summary:
Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents often exhibit learning behaviors that are
not intuitively interpretable by human observers, which can result in
suboptimal feedback in collaborative teaching settings. Yet, how humans
perceive and interpret RL agent's learning behavior is largely unknown. In a
bottom-up approach with two experiments, this work provides a data-driven
understanding of the factors of human observers' understanding of the agent's
learning process. A novel, observation-based paradigm to directly assess human
inferences about agent learning was developed. In an exploratory interview
study (\textit{N}=9), we identify four core themes in human interpretations:
Agent Goals, Knowledge, Decision Making, and Learning Mechanisms. A second
confirmatory study (\textit{N}=34) applied an expanded version of the paradigm
across two tasks (navigation/manipulation) and two RL algorithms
(tabular/function approximation). Analyses of 816 responses confirmed the
reliability of the paradigm and refined the thematic framework, revealing how
these themes evolve over time and interrelate. Our findings provide a
human-centered understanding of how people make sense of agent learning,
offering actionable insights for designing interpretable RL systems and
improving transparency in Human-Robot Interaction.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how humans interpret the learning behaviors of Reinforcement Learning agents through a novel observation-based paradigm, revealing key themes in their understanding and providing insights for more interpretable RL systems.
AI.motivation: Understanding human perception of RL agents' learning is crucial for effective collaboration and teaching. Poor interpretability can result in suboptimal human feedback, affecting overall performance.
AI.method: Two experiments were conducted: an exploratory interview study with 9 participants identifying core themes of understanding, and a confirmatory study with 34 participants testing the refined thematic framework across different tasks and algorithms, collecting 816 responses.
AI.result: The studies revealed four core themes: Agent Goals, Knowledge, Decision Making, and Learning Mechanisms, which evolve and interrelate over time, confirming the reliability of the developed paradigm.
AI.conclusion: The findings enhance our understanding of human interpretations of RL learning, suggesting ways to design more interpretable RL systems for better Human-Robot Interaction.
key_contributions: Development of a novel observation-based paradigm to assess human inferences about RL learning
Identification of four core themes in human interpretation
Confirmation of the reliability of the thematic framework across multiple RL tasks and algorithms

title: Phonikud: Hebrew Grapheme-to-Phoneme Conversion for Real-Time Text-to-Speech
summary:
Real-time text-to-speech (TTS) for Modern Hebrew is challenging due to the
language's orthographic complexity. Existing solutions ignore crucial phonetic
features such as stress that remain underspecified even when vowel marks are
added. To address these limitations, we introduce Phonikud, a lightweight,
open-source Hebrew grapheme-to-phoneme (G2P) system that outputs
fully-specified IPA transcriptions. Our approach adapts an existing
diacritization model with lightweight adaptors, incurring negligible additional
latency. We also contribute the ILSpeech dataset of transcribed Hebrew speech
with IPA annotations, serving as a benchmark for Hebrew G2P and as training
data for TTS systems. Our results demonstrate that Phonikud G2P conversion more
accurately predicts phonemes from Hebrew text compared to prior methods, and
that this enables training of effective real-time Hebrew TTS models with
superior speed-accuracy trade-offs. We release our code, data, and models at
https://phonikud.github.io.

AI.tldr: Introducing Phonikud, a Hebrew G2P system that addresses TTS challenges by outputting fully-specified IPA transcriptions.
AI.motivation: The complexity of Modern Hebrew's orthography makes real-time TTS challenging, particularly due to underspecified phonetic features such as stress.
AI.method: We adapted an existing diacritization model with lightweight adaptors to create a G2P system that outputs IPA transcriptions with minimal latency.
AI.result: Phonikud G2P conversion outperforms prior methods in accuracy for phoneme prediction from Hebrew text, facilitating the development of effective real-time Hebrew TTS models.
AI.conclusion: By providing a robust G2P model and a benchmark dataset, we enhance Hebrew TTS capabilities and open new avenues for research.
key_contributions: Introduction of Phonikud G2P system
Creation of the ILSpeech dataset with IPA annotations
Demonstration of improved speed-accuracy trade-offs in TTS models

title: Intersectional Bias in Japanese Large Language Models from a Contextualized Perspective
comment:
Accepted to the 6th Workshop on Gender Bias in Natural Language
  Processing (GeBNLP2025) at ACL2025
summary:
An growing number of studies have examined the social bias of rapidly
developed large language models (LLMs). Although most of these studies have
focused on bias occurring in a single social attribute, research in social
science has shown that social bias often occurs in the form of
intersectionality -- the constitutive and contextualized perspective on bias
aroused by social attributes. In this study, we construct the Japanese
benchmark inter-JBBQ, designed to evaluate the intersectional bias in LLMs on
the question-answering setting. Using inter-JBBQ to analyze GPT-4o and Swallow,
we find that biased output varies according to its contexts even with the equal
combination of social attributes.

AI.tldr: This study presents the inter-JBBQ benchmark to evaluate intersectional bias in large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4o and Swallow in question-answering contexts.
AI.motivation: To address the limitation in existing studies that focus on bias linked to single social attributes, highlighting the need for understanding intersectionality in social bias within LLMs.
AI.method: The researchers constructed the inter-JBBQ benchmark to evaluate intersectional bias in LLMs and applied it to analyze the outputs of GPT-4o and Swallow in various contexts.
AI.result: The analysis revealed that biased outputs from the models varied depending on contextual factors, even with an equal combination of social attributes.
AI.conclusion: Understanding intersectional bias is crucial for evaluating the fairness of LLMs, as the context significantly affects the manifestation of bias.
key_contributions: Development of the inter-JBBQ benchmark for assessing intersectional bias in LLMs
Demonstration of how contextual factors influence bias output in question-answering
Evaluation of intersectional biases in prominent LLMs like GPT-4o and Swallow
AI.limitations: The study focuses on a specific benchmark and may not generalize to all LLMs or contexts outside question-answering.

title: The Behavior Gap: Evaluating Zero-shot LLM Agents in Complex Task-Oriented Dialogs
summary:
Large Language Model (LLM)-based agents have significantly impacted
Task-Oriented Dialog Systems (TODS) but continue to face notable performance
challenges, especially in zero-shot scenarios. While prior work has noted this
performance gap, the behavioral factors driving the performance gap remain
under-explored. This study proposes a comprehensive evaluation framework to
quantify the behavior gap between AI agents and human experts, focusing on
discrepancies in dialog acts, tool usage, and knowledge utilization. Our
findings reveal that this behavior gap is a critical factor negatively
impacting the performance of LLM agents. Notably, as task complexity increases,
the behavior gap widens (correlation: 0.963), leading to a degradation of agent
performance on complex task-oriented dialogs. For the most complex task in our
study, even the GPT-4o-based agent exhibits low alignment with human behavior,
with low F1 scores for dialog acts (0.464), excessive and often misaligned tool
usage with a F1 score of 0.139, and ineffective usage of external knowledge.
Reducing such behavior gaps leads to significant performance improvement (24.3%
on average). This study highlights the importance of comprehensive behavioral
evaluations and improved alignment strategies to enhance the effectiveness of
LLM-based TODS in handling complex tasks.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates the performance gap between LLM-based agents and human experts in task-oriented dialog systems, focusing on behavior discrepancies that negatively impact performance.
AI.motivation: To address the notable performance challenges faced by LLM-based agents in task-oriented dialog systems, particularly under zero-shot conditions, by exploring the behavioral factors contributing to these challenges.
AI.method: A comprehensive evaluation framework was proposed to quantify the behavior gap by analyzing discrepancies in dialog acts, tool usage, and knowledge utilization between AI agents and human experts.
AI.result: Findings indicate a strong correlation (0.963) between task complexity and behavior gap, with GPT-4o-based agents showing low alignment with human behavior, particularly in complex tasks, leading to suboptimal performance.
AI.conclusion: Reducing behavior gaps can significantly enhance LLM-based agents' performance in task-oriented dialogs, emphasizing the necessity for improved behavioral evaluations and alignment strategies.
key_contributions: Proposed a framework to quantify the behavior gap in LLM agents versus human experts.
Revealed strong correlations between task complexity and performance degradation due to behavior gaps.
Highlighted the significance of behavioral evaluations in improving LLM agent performance.
AI.limitations: Limited to specific tasks and may not generalize across all types of task-oriented dialogs.

title: Investigating the Effects of Cognitive Biases in Prompts on Large Language Model Outputs
summary:
This paper investigates the influence of cognitive biases on Large Language
Models (LLMs) outputs. Cognitive biases, such as confirmation and availability
biases, can distort user inputs through prompts, potentially leading to
unfaithful and misleading outputs from LLMs. Using a systematic framework, our
study introduces various cognitive biases into prompts and assesses their
impact on LLM accuracy across multiple benchmark datasets, including general
and financial Q&A scenarios. The results demonstrate that even subtle biases
can significantly alter LLM answer choices, highlighting a critical need for
bias-aware prompt design and mitigation strategy. Additionally, our attention
weight analysis highlights how these biases can alter the internal
decision-making processes of LLMs, affecting the attention distribution in ways
that are associated with output inaccuracies. This research has implications
for Al developers and users in enhancing the robustness and reliability of Al
applications in diverse domains.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates how cognitive biases affect the outputs of Large Language Models (LLMs), emphasizing the need for bias-aware prompt design.
AI.motivation: Cognitive biases can distort user inputs, leading to misleading outputs from LLMs, necessitating an understanding of their influence on AI interactions.
AI.method: The study systematically introduced various cognitive biases into prompts and assessed their impact on LLM accuracy using multiple benchmark datasets for general and financial Q&A scenarios.
AI.result: The results showed that subtle biases significantly altered LLM answer choices, indicating a critical need for awareness in prompt design to mitigate these effects.
AI.conclusion: Bias-aware design strategies are essential for enhancing the reliability of AI applications by addressing the internal decision-making processes influenced by cognitive biases.
key_contributions: Introduced a systematic framework for assessing cognitive biases in LLM prompts.
Demonstrated the significant impact of cognitive biases on LLM accuracy across various benchmarks.
Highlighted the need for bias-aware strategies in LLM prompt design.

title: Refract ICL: Rethinking Example Selection in the Era of Million-Token Models
summary:
The emergence of long-context large language models (LLMs) has enabled the
use of hundreds, or even thousands, of demonstrations for in-context learning
(ICL) - a previously impractical regime. This paper investigates whether
traditional ICL selection strategies, which balance the similarity of ICL
examples to the test input (using a text retriever) with diversity within the
ICL set, remain effective when utilizing a large number of demonstrations. Our
experiments demonstrate that, while longer contexts can accommodate more
examples, simply increasing the number of demonstrations does not guarantee
improved performance. Smart ICL selection remains crucial, even with thousands
of demonstrations. To further enhance ICL in this setting, we introduce Refract
ICL, a novel ICL selection algorithm specifically designed to focus LLM
attention on challenging examples by strategically repeating them within the
context and incorporating zero-shot predictions as error signals. Our results
show that Refract ICL significantly improves the performance of extremely
long-context models such as Gemini 1.5 Pro, particularly on tasks with a
smaller number of output classes.

AI.tldr: This paper explores in-context learning (ICL) with long-context language models, introducing a novel algorithm called Refract ICL to improve performance through smart example selection.
AI.motivation: To evaluate the effectiveness of traditional ICL selection strategies when using large numbers of demonstrations with long-context LLMs, as performance does not necessarily improve with more examples.
AI.method: Experiments were conducted to compare traditional ICL selection methods with the proposed Refract ICL algorithm, which focuses on repeating challenging examples and uses zero-shot predictions as feedback.
AI.result: Refract ICL outperformed traditional methods in utilizing long-context LLMs, improving task performance, especially with fewer output classes.
AI.conclusion: Effective ICL selection remains essential even with thousands of examples; Refract ICL provides a significant advancement in how LLMs can learn from large context inputs.
key_contributions: Introduction of Refract ICL, a new example selection algorithm
Demonstration of improved performance in long-context models
Analysis of ICL selection strategies and their impacts on learning effectiveness

title: Efficient Reasoning Through Suppression of Self-Affirmation Reflections in Large Reasoning Models
summary:
While recent advances in large reasoning models have demonstrated remarkable
performance, efficient reasoning remains critical due to the rapid growth of
output length. Existing optimization approaches highlights a tendency toward
"overthinking", yet lack fine-grained analysis. In this work, we focus on
Self-Affirmation Reflections: redundant reflective steps that affirm prior
content and often occurs after the already correct reasoning steps.
Observations of both original and optimized reasoning models reveal pervasive
self-affirmation reflections. Notably, these reflections sometimes lead to
longer outputs in optimized models than their original counterparts. Through
detailed analysis, we uncover an intriguing pattern: compared to other
reflections, the leading words (i.e., the first word of sentences) in
self-affirmation reflections exhibit a distinct probability bias. Motivated by
this insight, we can locate self-affirmation reflections and conduct a
train-free experiment demonstrating that suppressing self-affirmation
reflections reduces output length without degrading accuracy across multiple
models (R1-Distill-Models, QwQ-32B, and Qwen3-32B). Furthermore, we also
improve current train-based method by explicitly suppressing such reflections.
In our experiments, we achieve length compression of 18.7\% in train-free
settings and 50.2\% in train-based settings for R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B. Moreover,
our improvements are simple yet practical and can be directly applied to
existing inference frameworks, such as vLLM. We believe that our findings will
provide community insights for achieving more precise length compression and
step-level efficient reasoning.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates self-affirmation reflections in reasoning models, demonstrating that they can lead to unnecessary output length and proposing methods to reduce it without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.motivation: With the rise of large reasoning models, there is a growing need for efficient reasoning to manage output length while maintaining performance.
AI.method: The study analyzes self-affirmation reflections and their patterns in output from reasoning models. It includes train-free experiments that suppress these reflections.
AI.result: The results show a length compression of 18.7% in train-free settings and 50.2% in train-based settings without degrading accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest practical improvements for length compression in reasoning models and provide insights for the community.
key_contributions: Identification of self-affirmation reflections as a cause of unnecessary output length.
Demonstration of significant output length reduction while maintaining accuracy.
Practical methods that can be integrated into existing inference frameworks.

title: Improving Factuality for Dialogue Response Generation via Graph-Based Knowledge Augmentation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) succeed in many natural language processing
tasks. However, their tendency to hallucinate - generate plausible but
inconsistent or factually incorrect text - can cause problems in certain tasks,
including response generation in dialogue. To mitigate this issue,
knowledge-augmented methods have shown promise in reducing hallucinations.
Here, we introduce a novel framework designed to enhance the factuality of
dialogue response generation, as well as an approach to evaluate dialogue
factual accuracy. Our framework combines a knowledge triple retriever, a
dialogue rewrite, and knowledge-enhanced response generation to produce more
accurate and grounded dialogue responses. To further evaluate generated
responses, we propose a revised fact score that addresses the limitations of
existing fact-score methods in dialogue settings, providing a more reliable
assessment of factual consistency. We evaluate our methods using different
baselines on the OpendialKG and HybriDialogue datasets. Our methods
significantly improve factuality compared to other graph knowledge-augmentation
baselines, including the state-of-the-art G-retriever. The code will be
released on GitHub.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework to enhance factual accuracy in dialogue response generation using knowledge augmentation and a revised evaluation method for dialogue factual accuracy.
AI.motivation: To address the issue of hallucination in Large Language Models (LLMs) during dialogue response generation, which can lead to the production of factually incorrect text.
AI.method: The framework incorporates a knowledge triple retriever, a dialogue rewrite process, and knowledge-enhanced response generation to create grounded dialogue responses. It also proposes a revised fact score for better evaluation of factual accuracy in generated dialogues.
AI.result: The proposed methods significantly improve the factuality of responses when tested against various baselines on the OpendialKG and HybriDialogue datasets, outperforming existing graph knowledge-augmentation techniques, including the G-retriever.
AI.conclusion: This framework not only enhances the accuracy of dialogue generation but also offers an improved metric for assessing factual consistency in dialogue contexts.
key_contributions: Introduction of a novel framework for knowledge-augmented dialogue generation
Development of a revised fact score for evaluating dialogue factual accuracy
Demonstrated significant improvements in factuality over existing methods

title: Advances in LLMs with Focus on Reasoning, Adaptability, Efficiency and Ethics
summary:
This survey paper outlines the key developments in the field of Large
Language Models (LLMs), such as enhancing their reasoning skills, adaptability
to various tasks, increased computational efficiency, and ability to make
ethical decisions. The techniques that have been most effective in bridging the
gap between human and machine communications include the Chain-of-Thought
prompting, Instruction Tuning, and Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback.
The improvements in multimodal learning and few-shot or zero-shot techniques
have further empowered LLMs to handle complex jobs with minor input. They also
manage to do more with less by applying scaling and optimization tricks for
computing power conservation. This survey also offers a broader perspective on
recent advancements in LLMs going beyond isolated aspects such as model
architecture or ethical concerns. It categorizes emerging methods that enhance
LLM reasoning, efficiency, and ethical alignment. It also identifies
underexplored areas such as interpretability, cross-modal integration and
sustainability. With recent progress, challenges like huge computational costs,
biases, and ethical risks remain constant. Addressing these requires bias
mitigation, transparent decision-making, and clear ethical guidelines. Future
research will focus on enhancing models ability to handle multiple input,
thereby making them more intelligent, safe, and reliable.

AI.tldr: This survey reviews advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs), focusing on their reasoning abilities, adaptability, computational efficiency, and ethical decisions.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive overview of the developments in LLMs and their implications for human-machine communication and ethical considerations.
AI.method: Surveying and categorizing emerging techniques that improve LLM abilities including Chain-of-Thought prompting, Instruction Tuning, and Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback, alongside discussing improvements in multimodal learning and few-shot/zero-shot techniques.
AI.result: Identified key techniques that bridge gaps in human-machine interactions and categorized enhancements in LLM reasoning, efficiency, and ethical alignment.
AI.conclusion: Future research should address challenges of computational costs, biases, and ethical risks, focusing on interpretability and cross-modal integration to enhance the reliability of LLMs.
key_contributions: Comprehensive survey of LLM advancements
Categorization of emerging methods for enhanced reasoning and efficiency
Identification of underexplored areas in LLM research
AI.limitations: The paper does not provide solutions to the challenges of computational costs, biases, and ethical risks but highlights the need for future research in these areas.

title: Understanding the Effect of Knowledge Graph Extraction Error on Downstream Graph Analyses: A Case Study on Affiliation Graphs
summary:
Knowledge graphs (KGs) are useful for analyzing social structures, community
dynamics, institutional memberships, and other complex relationships across
domains from sociology to public health. While recent advances in large
language models (LLMs) have improved the scalability and accessibility of
automated KG extraction from large text corpora, the impacts of extraction
errors on downstream analyses are poorly understood, especially for applied
scientists who depend on accurate KGs for real-world insights. To address this
gap, we conducted the first evaluation of KG extraction performance at two
levels: (1) micro-level edge accuracy, which is consistent with standard NLP
evaluations, and manual identification of common error sources; (2) macro-level
graph metrics that assess structural properties such as community detection and
connectivity, which are relevant to real-world applications. Focusing on
affiliation graphs of person membership in organizations extracted from social
register books, our study identifies a range of extraction performance where
biases across most downstream graph analysis metrics are near zero. However, as
extraction performance declines, we find that many metrics exhibit increasingly
pronounced biases, with each metric tending toward a consistent direction of
either over- or under-estimation. Through simulations, we further show that
error models commonly used in the literature do not capture these bias
patterns, indicating the need for more realistic error models for KG
extraction. Our findings provide actionable insights for practitioners and
underscores the importance of advancing extraction methods and error modeling
to ensure reliable and meaningful downstream analyses.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the performance of knowledge graph (KG) extraction methods, particularly focusing on the accuracy of extracted data and its impact on downstream analyses, highlighting biases introduced by extraction errors.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the need for understanding the impacts of KG extraction errors on analyses relevant to applied scientists, especially in fields like public health.
AI.method: The evaluation of KG extraction performance was conducted at two levels: micro-level edge accuracy through standard NLP evaluations and macro-level assessments of structural properties in graphs, using simulations to understand bias patterns.
AI.result: The study finds that while some extraction performance biases are minimal, significant biases appear when extraction performance declines, influencing important graph analysis metrics like community detection and connectivity.
AI.conclusion: The findings reveal shortcomings in current error models used for KG extraction and suggest the need for improved methods to ensure reliability in downstream analyses.
key_contributions: First evaluation of KG extraction performance at both micro and macro levels.
Identification of bias patterns in downstream graph analysis metrics based on extraction performance.
Call for more realistic error models for KG extraction to improve reliability.
AI.limitations: Focus on affiliation graphs from social register books may limit generalizability to other contexts.

title: Training-free LLM Merging for Multi-task Learning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated exceptional capabilities
across diverse natural language processing (NLP) tasks. The release of
open-source LLMs like LLaMA and Qwen has triggered the development of numerous
fine-tuned models tailored for various tasks and languages. In this paper, we
explore an important question: is it possible to combine these specialized
models to create a unified model with multi-task capabilities. We introduces
Hierarchical Iterative Merging (Hi-Merging), a training-free method for
unifying different specialized LLMs into a single model. Specifically,
Hi-Merging employs model-wise and layer-wise pruning and scaling, guided by
contribution analysis, to mitigate parameter conflicts. Extensive experiments
on multiple-choice and question-answering tasks in both Chinese and English
validate Hi-Merging's ability for multi-task learning. The results demonstrate
that Hi-Merging consistently outperforms existing merging techniques and
surpasses the performance of models fine-tuned on combined datasets in most
scenarios. Code is available at:
https://github.com/Applied-Machine-Learning-Lab/Hi-Merging.

AI.tldr: Exploration of combining specialized LLMs into a multi-task capable unified model using a new method called Hierarchical Iterative Merging (Hi-Merging).
AI.motivation: To determine if specialized language models can be unified into a single model with multi-task capabilities, addressing the challenge of combining differing models effectively.
AI.method: Hi-Merging uses model-wise and layer-wise pruning and scaling, guided by contribution analysis, to reduce parameter conflicts without the need for additional training.
AI.result: Experiments on multiple-choice and question-answering tasks reveal that Hi-Merging outperforms existing fusion techniques and surpasses fine-tuned models on combined datasets.
AI.conclusion: Hi-Merging is an effective approach for unifying specialized LLMs, demonstrating superior performance across various tasks compared to previous methods.
key_contributions: Introduction of Hi-Merging method for unifying LLMs
Improvement in multi-task learning effectiveness
Validation through extensive experiments in multiple languages

title: Recent Advances and Future Directions in Literature-Based Discovery
summary:
The explosive growth of scientific publications has created an urgent need
for automated methods that facilitate knowledge synthesis and hypothesis
generation. Literature-based discovery (LBD) addresses this challenge by
uncovering previously unknown associations between disparate domains. This
article surveys recent methodological advances in LBD, focusing on developments
from 2000 to the present. We review progress in three key areas: knowledge
graph construction, deep learning approaches, and the integration of
pre-trained and large language models (LLMs). While LBD has made notable
progress, several fundamental challenges remain unresolved, particularly
concerning scalability, reliance on structured data, and the need for extensive
manual curation. By examining ongoing advances and outlining promising future
directions, this survey underscores the transformative role of LLMs in
enhancing LBD and aims to support researchers and practitioners in harnessing
these technologies to accelerate scientific innovation.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys advancements in literature-based discovery (LBD) from 2000 to present, focusing on knowledge graph construction, deep learning, and LLM integration, highlighting both progress and unresolved challenges.
AI.motivation: To address the need for automated methods in synthesizing knowledge and generating hypotheses amid the growing volume of scientific literature.
AI.method: Survey of recent methodological advancements in LBD, analyzing knowledge graph construction techniques, deep learning approaches, and LLM integration since 2000.
AI.result: The paper identifies significant progress in LBD methodologies but notes ongoing challenges like scalability and the need for manual curation.
AI.conclusion: The survey emphasizes the promising role of LLMs in advancing LBD and offers future directions for research to enhance scientific innovation.
key_contributions: Comprehensive review of LBD methodologies and advancements since 2000.
Highlighting the impact of LLMs on knowledge synthesis.
Identification of challenges that need to be addressed for effective LBD implementation.
AI.limitations: Challenges like scalability, dependency on structured data, and extensive manual curation still persist in LBD methods.

title: Group then Scale: Dynamic Mixture-of-Experts Multilingual Language Model
comment:
ACL 2025, our codes and models are available at
  https://github.com/ZNLP/DMoE
summary:
The curse of multilinguality phenomenon is a fundamental problem of
multilingual Large Language Models (LLMs), where the competition between
massive languages results in inferior performance. It mainly comes from limited
capacity and negative transfer between dissimilar languages. To address this
issue, we propose a method to dynamically group and scale up the parameters of
multilingual LLM while boosting positive transfer among similar languages.
Specifically, the model is first tuned on monolingual corpus to determine the
parameter deviation in each layer and quantify the similarity between
languages. Layers with more deviations are extended to mixture-of-experts
layers to reduce competition between languages, where one expert module serves
one group of similar languages. Experimental results on 18 to 128 languages
show that our method reduces the negative transfer between languages and
significantly boosts multilingual performance with fewer parameters. Such
language group specialization on experts benefits the new language adaptation
and reduces the inference on the previous multilingual knowledge learned.

AI.tldr: Proposes a method to improve multilingual performance in LLMs by dynamically grouping parameters and reducing language competition.
AI.motivation: To address the curse of multilinguality, which hampers performance in multilingual LLMs due to competition between languages and limited capacity.
AI.method: The model is tuned on monolingual corpora to measure parameter deviation and quantify language similarity, leading to the conversion of layers into mixture-of-experts layers for better language grouping.
AI.result: Experimental results demonstrate reduced negative transfer and improved multilingual performance with fewer parameters across 18 to 128 languages.
AI.conclusion: Language group specialization enhances new language adaptation and mitigates earlier multilingual knowledge loss during inference.
key_contributions: Dynamic parameter grouping in multilingual LLMs
Mixture-of-experts layers to enhance language specialization
Quantification of language similarity for improved performance

title: Exploring Cultural Variations in Moral Judgments with Large Language Models
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown strong performance across many tasks,
but their ability to capture culturally diverse moral values remains unclear.
In this paper, we examine whether LLMs can mirror variations in moral attitudes
reported by two major cross-cultural surveys: the World Values Survey and the
PEW Research Center's Global Attitudes Survey. We compare smaller, monolingual,
and multilingual models (GPT-2, OPT, BLOOMZ, and Qwen) with more recent
instruction-tuned models (GPT-4o, GPT-4o-mini, Gemma-2-9b-it, and
Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct). Using log-probability-based moral justifiability
scores, we correlate each model's outputs with survey data covering a broad set
of ethical topics. Our results show that many earlier or smaller models often
produce near-zero or negative correlations with human judgments. In contrast,
advanced instruction-tuned models (including GPT-4o and GPT-4o-mini) achieve
substantially higher positive correlations, suggesting they better reflect
real-world moral attitudes. While scaling up model size and using instruction
tuning can improve alignment with cross-cultural moral norms, challenges remain
for certain topics and regions. We discuss these findings in relation to bias
analysis, training data diversity, and strategies for improving the cultural
sensitivity of LLMs.

AI.tldr: This study investigates the capacity of large language models to reflect culturally diverse moral values by comparing correlations with cross-cultural survey data.
AI.motivation: To determine if large language models (LLMs) can capture variations in moral attitudes across different cultures as measured by prominent surveys.
AI.method: The research compares outputs from smaller models (GPT-2, OPT, BLOOMZ, Qwen) and advanced instruction-tuned models (GPT-4o, GPT-4o-mini, Gemma-2-9b-it, and Llama-3.3-70B-Instruct) using log-probability-based moral justifiability scores.
AI.result: Instruction-tuned models like GPT-4o show significantly higher positive correlations with human moral judgments compared to smaller models, indicating improved alignment with real-world moral attitudes.
AI.conclusion: While larger and instruction-tuned models improve cultural sensitivity to moral norms, challenges persist for specific topics and regions, highlighting the need for better training data diversity.
key_contributions: Demonstrated the varying ability of LLMs to mirror cross-cultural moral attitudes
Highlighted the importance of model size and instruction tuning for ethical alignment
Discussed implications for bias analysis and cultural sensitivity in AI
AI.limitations: Certain topics and regions remain challenging for aligning LLMs with human moral judgments.

title: From Outcomes to Processes: Guiding PRM Learning from ORM for Inference-Time Alignment
summary:
Inference-time alignment methods have gained significant attention for their
efficiency and effectiveness in aligning large language models (LLMs) with
human preferences. However, existing dominant approaches using reward-guided
search (RGS) primarily rely on outcome reward models (ORMs), which suffer from
a critical granularity mismatch: ORMs are designed to provide outcome rewards
for complete responses, while RGS methods rely on process rewards to guide the
policy, leading to inconsistent scoring and suboptimal alignment. To address
this challenge, we introduce process reward models (PRMs) into RGS and argue
that an ideal PRM should satisfy two objectives: Score Consistency, ensuring
coherent evaluation across partial and complete responses, and Preference
Consistency, aligning partial sequence assessments with human preferences.
Based on these, we propose SP-PRM, a novel dual-consistency framework
integrating score consistency-based and preference consistency-based partial
evaluation modules without relying on human annotation. Extensive experiments
on dialogue, summarization, and reasoning tasks demonstrate that SP-PRM
substantially enhances existing RGS methods, achieving a 3.6%-10.3% improvement
in GPT-4 evaluation scores across all tasks.

AI.tldr: Introducing SP-PRM, a novel framework to improve reward-guided search alignment of LLMs with human preferences by integrating process reward models for enhanced consistency in scoring.
AI.motivation: Align large language models (LLMs) with human preferences more effectively by addressing limitations in existing reward-guided search methods that use outcome reward models.
AI.method: Propose a new framework, SP-PRM, which integrates score consistency and preference consistency evaluation modules for reward-guided search without human annotation.
AI.result: SP-PRM demonstrates significant improvements in evaluation scores, enhancing performance in dialogue, summarization, and reasoning tasks by 3.6%-10.3%.
AI.conclusion: Integrating process reward models into the RGS framework leads to better alignment of LLM outputs with human preferences.
key_contributions: Development of the SP-PRM framework addressing granularity mismatch in LLM evaluations.
Enhancement of existing reward-guided search methods through improved scoring consistency.
Implementation without reliance on human annotations.

title: Language Surgery in Multilingual Large Language Models
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable generalization
capabilities across tasks and languages, revolutionizing natural language
processing. This paper investigates the naturally emerging representation
alignment in LLMs, particularly in the middle layers, and its implications for
disentangling language-specific and language-agnostic information. We
empirically confirm the existence of this alignment, analyze its behavior in
comparison to explicitly designed alignment models, and demonstrate its
potential for language-specific manipulation without semantic degradation.
Building on these findings, we propose Inference-Time Language Control (ITLC),
a novel method that leverages latent injection to enable precise cross-lingual
language control and mitigate language confusion in LLMs. Our experiments
highlight ITLC's strong cross-lingual control capabilities while preserving
semantic integrity in target languages. Furthermore, we demonstrate its
effectiveness in alleviating the cross-lingual language confusion problem,
which persists even in current large-scale LLMs, leading to inconsistent
language generation. This work advances our understanding of representation
alignment in LLMs and introduces a practical solution for enhancing their
cross-lingual performance.

AI.tldr: This paper explores representation alignment in large language models (LLMs) and proposes a method for enhancing cross-lingual control while maintaining semantic integrity.
AI.motivation: To investigate representation alignment in LLMs and its impact on disentangling language-specific and language-agnostic information.
AI.method: The authors empirically confirm the existence of representation alignment in the middle layers of LLMs and propose Inference-Time Language Control (ITLC) to address language-specific manipulation and cross-lingual confusion.
AI.result: ITLC demonstrates strong cross-lingual control capabilities without semantic degradation, effectively alleviating language confusion in LLMs.
AI.conclusion: The findings enhance the understanding of representation alignment in LLMs and offer a practical method to improve cross-lingual performance.
key_contributions: Empirical confirmation of representation alignment in LLMs' middle layers.
Introduction of Inference-Time Language Control (ITLC) for cross-lingual manipulation.
Evidence of ITLC's effectiveness in preserving semantic integrity during language generation.

title: A Pluggable Multi-Task Learning Framework for Sentiment-Aware Financial Relation Extraction
summary:
Relation Extraction (RE) aims to extract semantic relationships in texts from
given entity pairs, and has achieved significant improvements. However, in
different domains, the RE task can be influenced by various factors. For
example, in the financial domain, sentiment can affect RE results, yet this
factor has been overlooked by modern RE models. To address this gap, this paper
proposes a Sentiment-aware-SDP-Enhanced-Module (SSDP-SEM), a multi-task
learning approach for enhancing financial RE. Specifically, SSDP-SEM integrates
the RE models with a pluggable auxiliary sentiment perception (ASP) task,
enabling the RE models to concurrently navigate their attention weights with
the text's sentiment. We first generate detailed sentiment tokens through a
sentiment model and insert these tokens into an instance. Then, the ASP task
focuses on capturing nuanced sentiment information through predicting the
sentiment token positions, combining both sentiment insights and the Shortest
Dependency Path (SDP) of syntactic information. Moreover, this work employs a
sentiment attention information bottleneck regularization method to regulate
the reasoning process. Our experiment integrates this auxiliary task with
several prevalent frameworks, and the results demonstrate that most previous
models benefit from the auxiliary task, thereby achieving better results. These
findings highlight the importance of effectively leveraging sentiment in the
financial RE task.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel approach to enhance Relation Extraction (RE) in the financial domain by integrating a sentiment-aware component into existing models.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the oversight of sentiment factors in modern RE models, particularly in the financial domain where sentiment can significantly impact results.
AI.method: The authors propose a Sentiment-aware-SDP-Enhanced-Module (SSDP-SEM) that employs multi-task learning to combine RE with an auxiliary sentiment perception task, enabling models to consider sentiment in their attention mechanisms.
AI.result: Experimental results show that incorporating the auxiliary sentiment perception task improves the performance of traditional RE frameworks on financial datasets.
AI.conclusion: The study emphasizes the importance of sentiment in enhancing Relation Extraction tasks, particularly in financial contexts, and demonstrates that existing models can benefit from this approach.
key_contributions: Introduction of a sentiment-aware component for financial Relation Extraction
Development of a multi-task learning framework that integrates sentiment analysis with RE
Demonstration of significant performance improvements in RE tasks when leveraging sentiment information.

title: TagRouter: Learning Route to LLMs through Tags for Open-Domain Text Generation Tasks
summary:
Model routing allocates queries to the suitable model, improving system
performance while reducing costs. However, existing routing methods face
practical limitations that hinder scalability in large-scale applications and
struggle to keep up with the rapid growth of the large language model (LLM)
ecosystem. To tackle these challenges, we propose TagRouter, a training-free
model routing method designed to optimize the synergy among multiple LLMs for
open-domain text generation tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that
TagRouter outperforms 13 baseline methods, increasing the accept rate of system
by 6.15% and reducing costs by 17.20%, achieving optimal cost-efficiency. Our
findings provides the LLM community with an efficient and scalable solution for
model ensembling, offering users an evolvable "super model."

AI.tldr: TagRouter is a training-free model routing method that enhances system performance and reduces costs in large-scale LLM applications.
AI.motivation: Existing model routing methods have scalability issues in large applications and cannot keep up with rapid LLM ecosystem growth.
AI.method: TagRouter optimizes the efficiency of model routing without requiring additional training, focusing on open-domain text generation tasks.
AI.result: TagRouter outperforms 13 baseline methods: it increases the accept rate by 6.15% and lowers costs by 17.20%.
AI.conclusion: TagRouter provides a scalable and efficient solution for model ensembling in the LLM community.
key_contributions: Training-free model routing method
Improved accept rates and reduced costs
Scalable solution for model ensembling

title: FlexRAG: A Flexible and Comprehensive Framework for Retrieval-Augmented Generation
summary:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) plays a pivotal role in modern large
language model applications, with numerous existing frameworks offering a wide
range of functionalities to facilitate the development of RAG systems. However,
we have identified several persistent challenges in these frameworks, including
difficulties in algorithm reproduction and sharing, lack of new techniques, and
high system overhead. To address these limitations, we introduce
\textbf{FlexRAG}, an open-source framework specifically designed for research
and prototyping. FlexRAG supports text-based, multimodal, and network-based
RAG, providing comprehensive lifecycle support alongside efficient asynchronous
processing and persistent caching capabilities. By offering a robust and
flexible solution, FlexRAG enables researchers to rapidly develop, deploy, and
share advanced RAG systems. Our toolkit and resources are available at
\href{https://github.com/ictnlp/FlexRAG}{https://github.com/ictnlp/FlexRAG}.

AI.tldr: FlexRAG is an open-source framework for developing versatile retrieval-augmented generation systems with support for text-based, multimodal, and network-based implementations.
AI.motivation: Existing frameworks for retrieval-augmented generation have persistent challenges such as algorithm reproduction issues, lack of innovative techniques, and high system overheads, necessitating a new solution.
AI.method: The authors introduce FlexRAG, which facilitates the development and prototyping of RAG systems with comprehensive lifecycle support, efficient asynchronous processing, and persistent caching.
AI.result: FlexRAG provides significant improvements in the development and sharing of advanced RAG systems.
AI.conclusion: This framework is a step forward in enhancing the capabilities and efficiency of RAG systems, making it easier for researchers to innovate and collaborate.
key_contributions: An open-source framework tailored for research and prototyping of RAG systems.
Support for diverse RAG system types: text-based, multimodal, and network-based.
Enhanced development lifecycle support with asynchronous processing and caching features.

title: Improving Factuality for Dialogue Response Generation via Graph-Based Knowledge Augmentation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) succeed in many natural language processing
tasks. However, their tendency to hallucinate - generate plausible but
inconsistent or factually incorrect text - can cause problems in certain tasks,
including response generation in dialogue. To mitigate this issue,
knowledge-augmented methods have shown promise in reducing hallucinations.
Here, we introduce a novel framework designed to enhance the factuality of
dialogue response generation, as well as an approach to evaluate dialogue
factual accuracy. Our framework combines a knowledge triple retriever, a
dialogue rewrite, and knowledge-enhanced response generation to produce more
accurate and grounded dialogue responses. To further evaluate generated
responses, we propose a revised fact score that addresses the limitations of
existing fact-score methods in dialogue settings, providing a more reliable
assessment of factual consistency. We evaluate our methods using different
baselines on the OpendialKG and HybriDialogue datasets. Our methods
significantly improve factuality compared to other graph knowledge-augmentation
baselines, including the state-of-the-art G-retriever. The code will be
released on GitHub.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework combining knowledge retrieval and dialogue rewriting to enhance the factuality of dialogue response generation from LLMs, addressing hallucination issues, and proposes a new evaluation metric for factual accuracy.
AI.motivation: To address the problem of hallucinations in large language models during dialogue generation which can cause the generation of factually incorrect responses.
AI.method: The proposed framework integrates a knowledge triple retriever, a dialogue rewrite process, and a knowledge-enhanced response generation mechanism. Additionally, it introduces a revised fact score for evaluating factual consistency.
AI.result: The results demonstrate that our methods significantly improve the factual accuracy of generated dialogue responses when compared to other graph knowledge-augmentation baselines, particularly the G-retriever.
AI.conclusion: Our approach effectively reduces hallucinations in LLM-generated dialogues and provides a more reliable method for assessing the factual consistency of responses.
key_contributions: Introduction of a novel framework for dialogue response generation.
Development of a knowledge-augmented approach to enhance factuality.
Proposal of a revised fact score for evaluating dialogue factual accuracy.
AI.limitations: Existing methods for evaluating factual accuracy in dialogue settings have limitations that our new fact score aims to address, but some inherent limitations of knowledge retrieval still apply.

title: Towards Fairness Assessment of Dutch Hate Speech Detection
comment:
Accepted for publication at the 9th Workshop on Online Abuse and
  Harms (WOAH) held in conjunction with ACL 2025
summary:
Numerous studies have proposed computational methods to detect hate speech
online, yet most focus on the English language and emphasize model development.
In this study, we evaluate the counterfactual fairness of hate speech detection
models in the Dutch language, specifically examining the performance and
fairness of transformer-based models. We make the following key contributions.
First, we curate a list of Dutch Social Group Terms that reflect social
context. Second, we generate counterfactual data for Dutch hate speech using
LLMs and established strategies like Manual Group Substitution (MGS) and
Sentence Log-Likelihood (SLL). Through qualitative evaluation, we highlight the
challenges of generating realistic counterfactuals, particularly with Dutch
grammar and contextual coherence. Third, we fine-tune baseline
transformer-based models with counterfactual data and evaluate their
performance in detecting hate speech. Fourth, we assess the fairness of these
models using Counterfactual Token Fairness (CTF) and group fairness metrics,
including equality of odds and demographic parity. Our analysis shows that
models perform better in terms of hate speech detection, average counterfactual
fairness and group fairness. This work addresses a significant gap in the
literature on counterfactual fairness for hate speech detection in Dutch and
provides practical insights and recommendations for improving both model
performance and fairness.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates counterfactual fairness in Dutch hate speech detection models, contributing data curation, counterfactual generation, and fairness assessments using transformer models.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of research on counterfactual fairness in hate speech detection for non-English languages, specifically Dutch.
AI.method: The study involves curating a list of Dutch Social Group Terms, generating counterfactual data using LLMs, and fine-tuning transformer-based models to evaluate their performance and fairness.
AI.result: Models improved in detecting hate speech with enhanced average counterfactual fairness and group fairness metrics compared to baseline models.
AI.conclusion: The work highlights the need for fairer hate speech detection methods and informs practices for translating these findings into model development.
key_contributions: Curated a list of Dutch Social Group Terms
Generated counterfactual data for hate speech detection
Evaluated the fairness of transformer models using Counterfactual Token Fairness metrics
AI.limitations: Challenges in generating realistic counterfactuals related to Dutch grammar and contextual coherence.

title: Aptly: Making Mobile Apps from Natural Language
summary:
This paper introduces Aptly, a platform designed to democratize mobile app
development, particularly for young learners. Aptly integrates a Large Language
Model (LLM) with App Inventor, enabling users to create apps using their
natural language. User's description is translated into a programming language
that corresponds with App Inventor's visual blocks. A preliminary study with
high school students demonstrated the usability and potential of the platform.
Prior programming experience influenced how users interact with Aptly.
Participants identified areas for improvement and expressed a shift in
perspective regarding programming accessibility and AI's role in creative
endeavors.

AI.tldr: Aptly is a platform that uses a Large Language Model to simplify mobile app development for young learners by translating natural language descriptions into programming with App Inventor.
AI.motivation: To democratize mobile app development and enhance programming accessibility for students without prior coding experience.
AI.method: Integration of an LLM with App Inventor to allow natural language input that generates visual programming blocks.
AI.result: A preliminary study showed good usability among high school students and indicated that prior programming knowledge affected how users utilized the platform.
AI.conclusion: Participants saw AI as a tool to make programming more accessible and offered suggestions for future improvements in Aptly.
key_contributions: Introduction of a natural language interface for mobile app development
Demonstration of LLM's application in educational contexts
Insights into user interactions and perceptions regarding programming accessibility
AI.limitations: The study was preliminary and focused on high school students, limiting the generalizability of the findings.

title: Detection, Classification, and Mitigation of Gender Bias in Large Language Models
summary:
With the rapid development of large language models (LLMs), they have
significantly improved efficiency across a wide range of domains. However,
recent studies have revealed that LLMs often exhibit gender bias, leading to
serious social implications. Detecting, classifying, and mitigating gender bias
in LLMs has therefore become a critical research focus. In the NLPCC 2025
Shared Task 7: Chinese Corpus for Gender Bias Detection, Classification and
Mitigation Challenge, we investigate how to enhance the capabilities of LLMs in
gender bias detection, classification, and mitigation. We adopt reinforcement
learning, chain-of-thoughts (CoT) reasoning, and supervised fine-tuning to
handle different Subtasks. Specifically, for Subtasks 1 and 2, we leverage the
internal reasoning capabilities of LLMs to guide multi-step thinking in a
staged manner, which simplifies complex biased queries and improves response
accuracy. For Subtask 3, we employ a reinforcement learning-based approach,
annotating a preference dataset using GPT-4. We then apply Direct Preference
Optimization (DPO) to mitigate gender bias by introducing a loss function that
explicitly favors less biased completions over biased ones. Our approach ranked
first across all three subtasks of the NLPCC 2025 Shared Task 7.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses gender bias in large language models (LLMs) by enhancing their detection, classification, and mitigation capabilities through various techniques including reinforcement learning and chain-of-thought reasoning, achieving top results in a shared task.
AI.motivation: The paper focuses on improving LLMs by addressing serious social implications of gender bias, which has been highlighted in recent studies.
AI.method: The authors used reinforcement learning, chain-of-thought reasoning, and supervised fine-tuning for different subtasks related to gender bias detection and mitigation.
AI.result: The proposed methods improved response accuracy and achieved first-ranked results across all subtasks in the NLPCC 2025 Shared Task 7.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates that employing advanced techniques like reinforcement learning and multi-step reasoning can effectively mitigate gender bias in LLMs.
key_contributions: Developed a novel approach using reinforcement learning for bias mitigation.
Leveraged chain-of-thought reasoning to improve accuracy in biased query responses.
Achieved first place in NLPCC 2025 Shared Task for gender bias tasks.

title: "I Always Felt that SomethingWasWrong.": Understanding Compliance Risks and Mitigation Strategies when Highly-Skilled Compliance KnowledgeWorkers Use Large Language Models
summary:
