The rapid advancement of Large Language Models (LLMs) has transformed
knowledge-intensive has led to its widespread usage by knowledge workers to
enhance their productivity. As these professionals handle sensitive
information, and the training of text-based GenAI models involves the use of
extensive data, there are thus concerns about privacy, security, and broader
compliance with regulations and laws. While existing research has addressed
privacy and security concerns, the specific compliance risks faced by
highly-skilled knowledge workers when using the LLMs, and their mitigation
strategies, remain underexplored. As understanding these risks and strategies
is crucial for the development of industry-specific compliant LLM mechanisms,
this research conducted semi-structured interviews with 24 knowledge workers
from knowledge-intensive industries to understand their practices and
experiences when integrating LLMs into their workflows. Our research explored
how these workers ensure compliance and the resources and challenges they
encounter when minimizing risks. Our preliminary findings showed that knowledge
workers were concerned about the leakage of sensitive information and took
proactive measures such as distorting input data and limiting prompt details to
mitigate such risks. Their ability to identify and mitigate risks, however, was
significantly hampered by a lack of LLM-specific compliance guidance and
training. Our findings highlight the importance of improving knowledge workers'
compliance awareness and establishing support systems and compliance cultures
within organizations.

AI.tldr: This research investigates compliance risks faced by knowledge workers using Large Language Models (LLMs) and explores strategies to mitigate these risks.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the gaps in understanding compliance risks related to the use of LLMs by knowledge workers, especially regarding privacy and security concerns associated with sensitive information.
AI.method: Semi-structured interviews were conducted with 24 knowledge workers from various knowledge-intensive industries to explore their experiences and practices in integrating LLMs into their workflows.
AI.result: Preliminary findings indicate that while knowledge workers are aware of the risk of sensitive information leakage and engage in practices to mitigate these risks, their efforts are hindered by a lack of specific compliance guidance and training for LLM usage.
AI.conclusion: The research underscores the need for better compliance guidance and awareness among knowledge workers when using LLMs, alongside the establishment of supportive compliance cultures in organizations.
key_contributions: Identified compliance risks for knowledge workers using LLMs
Proposed proactive measures taken by users to mitigate risks
Highlighted the need for compliance guidance and training specific to LLMs
AI.limitations: The study is based on a limited sample size of 24 knowledge workers, which may not represent all sectors.

title: Speech-Language Models with Decoupled Tokenizers and Multi-Token Prediction
summary:
Speech-language models (SLMs) offer a promising path toward unifying speech
and text understanding and generation. However, challenges remain in achieving
effective cross-modal alignment and high-quality speech generation. In this
work, we systematically investigate the impact of key components (i.e., speech
tokenizers, speech heads, and speaker modeling) on the performance of
LLM-centric SLMs. We compare coupled, semi-decoupled, and fully decoupled
speech tokenizers under a fair SLM framework and find that decoupled
tokenization significantly improves alignment and synthesis quality. To address
the information density mismatch between speech and text, we introduce
multi-token prediction (MTP) into SLMs, enabling each hidden state to decode
multiple speech tokens. This leads to up to 12$\times$ faster decoding and a
substantial drop in word error rate (from 6.07 to 3.01). Furthermore, we
propose a speaker-aware generation paradigm and introduce RoleTriviaQA, a
large-scale role-playing knowledge QA benchmark with diverse speaker
identities. Experiments demonstrate that our methods enhance both knowledge
understanding and speaker consistency.

AI.tldr: This paper explores improvements in speech-language models (SLMs) for better alignment and synthesis, focusing on tokenization and speaker modeling.
AI.motivation: To unify speech and text understanding and generation while addressing challenges in cross-modal alignment and speech generation quality.
AI.method: The authors systematically investigate the effects of speech tokenizers, speech heads, and speaker modeling on LLM-centric SLM performance, comparing coupled, semi-decoupled, and fully decoupled tokenizers.
AI.result: Decoupled tokenization significantly enhances alignment and synthesis quality, with the introduction of multi-token prediction leading to faster decoding (up to 12x) and reduced word error rates (from 6.07 to 3.01).
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods improve knowledge understanding and speaker consistency in SLMs, supported by the RoleTriviaQA benchmark for evaluation.
key_contributions: Introduction of multi-token prediction for improving decoding speed and accuracy.
Development of a speaker-aware generation paradigm.
Creation of the RoleTriviaQA benchmark for diverse speaker identities.

title: Towards Human-AI Synergy in UI Design: Enhancing Multi-Agent Based UI Generation with Intent Clarification and Alignment
summary:
In automated user interface (UI) design generation, a key challenge is the
lack of support for iterative processes, as most systems only focus on
end-to-end generation of designs as starting points. This results from (1)
limited capabilities to fully interpret user design intent from text or images,
and (2) a lack of transparency, which prevents designers from refining
intermediate results. To address existing limitations, we introduce
PrototypeAgent, a human-centered, multi-agent system for automated UI
generation. The core of PrototypeAgent is a theme design agent that clarifies
implicit design intent through prompt augmentation, coordinating with
specialized sub-agents to generate specific components. Designers interact with
the system via an intuitive interface, providing natural language descriptions
and layout preferences. During generation, PrototypeAgent enables designers to
refine generated intermediate guidance or specific components, ensuring
alignment with their intent throughout the generation workflow. Evaluations
through experiments and user studies show PrototypeAgent's effectiveness in
producing high-fidelity prototypes that accurately reflect design intent as
well as its superiority over baseline models in terms of both quality and
diversity.

AI.tldr: PrototypeAgent is a human-centered multi-agent system for automated UI generation that allows for iterative design refinement.
AI.motivation: Current automated UI design systems fail to support iterative processes and interpret user intents effectively, limiting design refinement.
AI.method: PrototypeAgent uses a theme design agent that enhances user prompts and coordinates with specialized sub-agents to create UI components based on user natural language inputs and layout preferences.
AI.result: PrototypeAgent has been shown to produce high-fidelity prototypes that align closely with user design intent, demonstrating superiority over existing models in both quality and diversity.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the effectiveness of PrototypeAgent in improving automated UI generation, allowing for better iterative design processes.
key_contributions: Introduction of a multi-agent system for UI design generation.
Integration of prompt augmentation to clarify user intent.
Allowing iterative refinement of design components during generation.
AI.limitations: The system's performance may vary based on the complexity of user inputs and the diversity of design components required.

title: RealFactBench: A Benchmark for Evaluating Large Language Models in Real-World Fact-Checking
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) hold significant potential for advancing
fact-checking by leveraging their capabilities in reasoning, evidence
retrieval, and explanation generation. However, existing benchmarks fail to
comprehensively evaluate LLMs and Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in
realistic misinformation scenarios. To bridge this gap, we introduce
RealFactBench, a comprehensive benchmark designed to assess the fact-checking
capabilities of LLMs and MLLMs across diverse real-world tasks, including
Knowledge Validation, Rumor Detection, and Event Verification. RealFactBench
consists of 6K high-quality claims drawn from authoritative sources,
encompassing multimodal content and diverse domains. Our evaluation framework
further introduces the Unknown Rate (UnR) metric, enabling a more nuanced
assessment of models' ability to handle uncertainty and balance between
over-conservatism and over-confidence. Extensive experiments on 7
representative LLMs and 4 MLLMs reveal their limitations in real-world
fact-checking and offer valuable insights for further research. RealFactBench
is publicly available at https://github.com/kalendsyang/RealFactBench.git.

AI.tldr: Introduction of RealFactBench, a benchmark for assessing the fact-checking capabilities of LLMs and MLLMs.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks do not fully evaluate LLMs and MLLMs in realistic scenarios of misinformation.
AI.method: RealFactBench evaluates fact-checking through a framework involving 6K claims from authoritative sources across various tasks like Knowledge Validation and Rumor Detection, focusing on handling uncertainty with the Unknown Rate (UnR) metric.
AI.result: Experiments on 7 LLMs and 4 MLLMs highlight their limitations in effective real-world fact-checking scenarios.
AI.conclusion: RealFactBench serves as a tool to enhance the evaluation of fact-checking capabilities in LLMs and MLLMs, available for public access.
key_contributions: Introduction of RealFactBench benchmark
Development of Unknown Rate (UnR) metric
Comprehensive evaluation framework for diverse fact-checking tasks.
AI.limitations: Limited to the claims sourced and evaluated with current model capabilities.

title: OS-Kairos: Adaptive Interaction for MLLM-Powered GUI Agents
summary:
Autonomous graphical user interface (GUI) agents powered by multimodal large
language models have shown great promise. However, a critical yet underexplored
issue persists: over-execution, where the agent executes tasks in a fully
autonomous way, without adequate assessment of its action confidence to
compromise an adaptive human-agent collaboration. This poses substantial risks
in complex scenarios, such as those involving ambiguous user instructions,
unexpected interruptions, and environmental hijacks. To address the issue, we
introduce OS-Kairos, an adaptive GUI agent capable of predicting confidence
levels at each interaction step and efficiently deciding whether to act
autonomously or seek human intervention. OS-Kairos is developed through two key
mechanisms: (i) collaborative probing that annotates confidence scores at each
interaction step; (ii) confidence-driven interaction that leverages these
confidence scores to elicit the ability of adaptive interaction. Experimental
results show that OS-Kairos substantially outperforms existing models on our
curated dataset featuring complex scenarios, as well as on established
benchmarks such as AITZ and Meta-GUI, with 24.59\%$\sim$87.29\% improvements in
task success rate. OS-Kairos facilitates an adaptive human-agent collaboration,
prioritizing effectiveness, generality, scalability, and efficiency for
real-world GUI interaction. The dataset and codes are available at
https://github.com/Wuzheng02/OS-Kairos.

AI.tldr: Introduction of OS-Kairos, an adaptive GUI agent addressing over-execution issues in autonomous agents by predicting confidence levels and facilitating human intervention.
AI.motivation: To tackle the issue of over-execution in autonomous GUI agents, which undermines effective human-agent collaboration, especially in complex scenarios.
AI.method: OS-Kairos employs collaborative probing for annotating confidence scores and confidence-driven interaction for adaptive decision-making on when to execute autonomously vs. seek human help.
AI.result: OS-Kairos shows significant improvements in task success rates, outperforming existing models by 24.59% to 87.29% on complex scenarios and established benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: OS-Kairos advances adaptive human-agent collaboration, emphasizing effectiveness and efficiency in real-world GUI interactions.
key_contributions: Introduction of OS-Kairos agent with confidence score prediction
Mechanisms for assessing interaction confidence
Demonstrated performance improvements over existing models

title: Profiling News Media for Factuality and Bias Using LLMs and the Fact-Checking Methodology of Human Experts
comment:
Accepted to Findings of the Association for Computational Linguistics
  (ACL) 2025
summary:
In an age characterized by the proliferation of mis- and disinformation
online, it is critical to empower readers to understand the content they are
reading. Important efforts in this direction rely on manual or automatic
fact-checking, which can be challenging for emerging claims with limited
information. Such scenarios can be handled by assessing the reliability and the
political bias of the source of the claim, i.e., characterizing entire news
outlets rather than individual claims or articles. This is an important but
understudied research direction. While prior work has looked into linguistic
and social contexts, we do not analyze individual articles or information in
social media. Instead, we propose a novel methodology that emulates the
criteria that professional fact-checkers use to assess the factuality and
political bias of an entire outlet. Specifically, we design a variety of
prompts based on these criteria and elicit responses from large language models
(LLMs), which we aggregate to make predictions. In addition to demonstrating
sizable improvements over strong baselines via extensive experiments with
multiple LLMs, we provide an in-depth error analysis of the effect of media
popularity and region on model performance. Further, we conduct an ablation
study to highlight the key components of our dataset that contribute to these
improvements. To facilitate future research, we released our dataset and code
at https://github.com/mbzuai-nlp/llm-media-profiling.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel methodology that uses LLMs to assess the reliability and political bias of news outlets, improving upon traditional fact-checking efforts.
AI.motivation: With the rise of misinformation online, there's a need to enable readers to understand the reliability and bias of their information sources instead of just fact-checking individual claims.
AI.method: The methodology involves designing prompts based on the criteria used by professional fact-checkers to evaluate entire news outlets and employing LLMs to predict reliability and bias.
AI.result: The proposed approach demonstrates significant improvements over baseline models in assessing outlet reliability and bias, as validated by extensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: The study provides insights into LLM performance based on media popularity and region, and emphasizes the importance of key dataset components for model effectiveness.
key_contributions: Introduction of a novel methodology for outlet assessment using LLMs.
Release of a dataset and code to facilitate further research.
Extensive error analysis highlighting factors affecting model performance.
AI.limitations: The research does not analyze individual articles or social media information directly.

title: DoTA-RAG: Dynamic of Thought Aggregation RAG
summary:
In this paper, we introduce DoTA-RAG (Dynamic-of-Thought Aggregation RAG), a
retrieval-augmented generation system optimized for high-throughput,
large-scale web knowledge indexes. Traditional RAG pipelines often suffer from
high latency and limited accuracy over massive, diverse datasets. DoTA-RAG
addresses these challenges with a three-stage pipeline: query rewriting,
dynamic routing to specialized sub-indexes, and multi-stage retrieval and
ranking. We further enhance retrieval by evaluating and selecting a superior
embedding model, re-embedding the large FineWeb-10BT corpus. Moreover, we
create a diverse Q&A dataset of 500 questions generated via the DataMorgana
setup across a broad range of WebOrganizer topics and formats. DoTA-RAG
improves the answer correctness score from 0.752 (baseline, using LiveRAG
pre-built vector store) to 1.478 while maintaining low latency, and it achieves
a 0.929 correctness score on the Live Challenge Day. These results highlight
DoTA-RAG's potential for practical deployment in domains requiring fast,
reliable access to large and evolving knowledge sources.

AI.tldr: DoTA-RAG is a dynamic retrieval-augmented generation system that improves accuracy and reduces latency for large web knowledge indexes.
AI.motivation: To address the high latency and limited accuracy in traditional retrieval-augmented generation systems over massive datasets.
AI.method: DoTA-RAG employs a three-stage pipeline involving query rewriting, dynamic routing to specialized sub-indexes, and multi-stage retrieval and ranking, alongside re-embedding a large corpus.
AI.result: DoTA-RAG increased the answer correctness score from 0.752 to 1.478 and achieved a correctness score of 0.929 during the Live Challenge Day.
AI.conclusion: The results show DoTA-RAG's effectiveness for fast and reliable access to extensive knowledge sources, indicating its potential for deployment in various applications.
key_contributions: Introduction of a three-stage pipeline for retrieval-augmented generation
Significant improvement in answer correctness scores
Creation of a diverse Q&A dataset for evaluation

title: Overview of the NLPCC 2025 Shared Task: Gender Bias Mitigation Challenge
summary:
As natural language processing for gender bias becomes a significant
interdisciplinary topic, the prevalent data-driven techniques, such as
pre-trained language models, suffer from biased corpus. This case becomes more
obvious regarding those languages with less fairness-related computational
linguistic resources, such as Chinese. To this end, we propose a Chinese cOrpus
foR Gender bIas Probing and Mitigation (CORGI-PM), which contains 32.9k
sentences with high-quality labels derived by following an annotation scheme
specifically developed for gender bias in the Chinese context. It is worth
noting that CORGI-PM contains 5.2k gender-biased sentences along with the
corresponding bias-eliminated versions rewritten by human annotators. We pose
three challenges as a shared task to automate the mitigation of textual gender
bias, which requires the models to detect, classify, and mitigate textual
gender bias. In the literature, we present the results and analysis for the
teams participating this shared task in NLPCC 2025.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces CORGI-PM, a Chinese corpus for probing and mitigating gender bias in natural language processing, and presents challenges for automated mitigation of bias.
AI.motivation: To address gender bias in natural language processing, particularly in languages like Chinese that lack fairness-related resources.
AI.method: Creation of the CORGI-PM dataset containing 32.9k sentences with annotations for gender bias, including biased and bias-eliminated sentences. Three challenges for automated bias mitigation were proposed.
AI.result: The dataset was highlighted for its high-quality labels and diverse examples, enabling effective detection and mitigation of gender bias.
AI.conclusion: The proposed challenges aim to advance the automation of detecting and mitigating gender bias in text, as illustrated by the participation results from NLPCC 2025.
key_contributions: Introduction of CORGI-PM dataset
Development of a specialized annotation scheme for gender bias in Chinese
Proposal of shared tasks for automating gender bias mitigation

title: Enabling Precise Topic Alignment in Large Language Models Via Sparse Autoencoders
summary:
Recent work shows that Sparse Autoencoders (SAE) applied to large language
model (LLM) layers have neurons corresponding to interpretable concepts. These
SAE neurons can be modified to align generated outputs, but only towards
pre-identified topics and with some parameter tuning. Our approach leverages
the observational and modification properties of SAEs to enable alignment for
any topic. This method 1) scores each SAE neuron by its semantic similarity to
an alignment text and uses them to 2) modify SAE-layer-level outputs by
emphasizing topic-aligned neurons. We assess the alignment capabilities of this
approach on diverse public topic datasets including Amazon reviews, Medicine,
and Sycophancy, across the currently available open-source LLMs and SAE pairs
(GPT2 and Gemma) with multiple SAEs configurations. Experiments aligning to
medical prompts reveal several benefits over fine-tuning, including increased
average language acceptability (0.25 vs. 0.5), reduced training time across
multiple alignment topics (333.6s vs. 62s), and acceptable inference time for
many applications (+0.00092s/token). Our open-source code is available at
github.com/IBM/sae-steering.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a method using Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) to align outputs of large language models (LLMs) to various topics by modifying output based on neuron scoring, demonstrating benefits over traditional fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: To enable flexible alignment of generated outputs from LLMs to any topic using Sparse Autoencoders, addressing limitations of existing methods confined to pre-identified topics.
AI.method: The proposed method scores each SAE neuron by its semantic similarity to an alignment text, modifying outputs by emphasizing neurons aligned with the target topic.
AI.result: The approach demonstrates improved average language acceptability and reduced training time across multiple topic alignments.
AI.conclusion: The method offers a significant alternative to fine-tuning with advantages in efficiency, presenting a viable way to align LLM outputs to diverse topics effectively.
key_contributions: Introduces a novel alignment method leveraging semantic similarity of SAE neurons to expand topic alignment capabilities.
Demonstrates significant improvements in alignment efficacy and training time compared to traditional fine-tuning methods.
Provides open-source code for practical applications in the HCI and NLP fields.
AI.limitations: The method requires careful selection of alignment texts and may still necessitate some tuning based on the application context.

title: OneEval: Benchmarking LLM Knowledge-intensive Reasoning over Diverse Knowledge Bases
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated substantial progress on
reasoning tasks involving unstructured text, yet their capabilities
significantly deteriorate when reasoning requires integrating structured
external knowledge such as knowledge graphs, code snippets, or formal logic.
This limitation is partly due to the absence of benchmarks capable of
systematically evaluating LLM performance across diverse structured knowledge
modalities. To address this gap, we introduce \textbf{\textsc{OneEval}}, a
comprehensive benchmark explicitly designed to assess the knowledge-intensive
reasoning capabilities of LLMs across four structured knowledge modalities,
unstructured text, knowledge graphs, code, and formal logic, and five critical
domains (general knowledge, government, science, law, and programming).
\textsc{OneEval} comprises 4,019 carefully curated instances and includes a
challenging subset, \textsc{OneEval}\textsubscript{Hard}, consisting of 1,285
particularly difficult cases. Through extensive evaluation of 18
state-of-the-art open-source and proprietary LLMs, we establish three core
findings: a) \emph{persistent limitations in structured reasoning}, with even
the strongest model achieving only 32.2\% accuracy on
\textsc{OneEval}\textsubscript{Hard}; b) \emph{performance consistently
declines as the structural complexity of the knowledge base increases}, with
accuracy dropping sharply from 53\% (textual reasoning) to 25\% (formal logic);
and c) \emph{diminishing returns from extended reasoning chains}, highlighting
the critical need for models to adapt reasoning depth appropriately to task
complexity. We release the \textsc{OneEval} datasets, evaluation scripts, and
baseline results publicly, accompanied by a leaderboard to facilitate ongoing
advancements in structured knowledge reasoning.

AI.tldr: Introduction of OneEval, a benchmark for assessing LLM capabilities in structured knowledge reasoning.
AI.motivation: To address the gap in evaluating LLM performance on structured knowledge tasks, as existing benchmarks are lacking.
AI.method: OneEval is a benchmark designed to evaluate LLMs across structured knowledge modalities and various domains, comprising 4,019 instances, including a challenging subset with 1,285 cases.
AI.result: Evaluation of 18 LLMs revealed persistent limitations in structured reasoning, performance decline with structural complexity, and diminishing returns from extended reasoning chains.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the necessity for models to adapt their reasoning strategies to task complexity; OneEval resources are publicly released for further research.
key_contributions: Introduction of OneEval benchmark for structured knowledge reasoning
Establishment of persistent limitations in LLM performance
Data release for ongoing research and evaluation
AI.limitations: The benchmark may not cover all possible reasoning scenarios and structured knowledge forms.

title: An Exploration of Mamba for Speech Self-Supervised Models
summary:
While Mamba has demonstrated strong performance in language modeling, its
potential as a speech self-supervised (SSL) model remains underexplored, with
prior studies limited to isolated tasks. To address this, we explore
Mamba-based HuBERT models as alternatives to Transformer-based SSL
architectures. Leveraging the linear-time Selective State Space, these models
enable fine-tuning on long-context ASR with significantly lower compute.
Moreover, they show superior performance when fine-tuned for streaming ASR.
Beyond fine-tuning, these models show competitive performance on SUPERB probing
benchmarks, particularly in causal settings. Our analysis shows that they yield
higher-quality quantized representations and capture speaker-related features
more distinctly than Transformer-based models. These findings highlight
Mamba-based SSL as a promising and complementary direction for long-sequence
modeling, real-time speech modeling, and speech unit extraction.

AI.tldr: Mamba-based HuBERT models are explored as alternatives for speech self-supervised learning, demonstrating advantages in performance and efficiency over Transformer-based models.
AI.motivation: To investigate the potential of Mamba in speech self-supervised learning, addressing the limitations of prior studies which focused on isolated tasks.
AI.method: The study utilizes Mamba-based HuBERT models in conjunction with the linear-time Selective State Space for long-context ASR fine-tuning.
AI.result: Mamba-based models achieve superior performance in streaming ASR and show competitive results on SUPERB probing benchmarks, with better quantized representations and clearer speaker feature capture compared to Transformers.
AI.conclusion: Mamba-based SSL is a promising avenue for improving long-sequence modeling and real-time speech applications.
key_contributions: Demonstrated strong performance of Mamba-based HuBERT in speech SSL tasks.
Achieved lower compute requirements while maintaining high performance for long-context ASR.
Outperformed Transformer-based models in capturing speaker-related features.

title: Towards Building General Purpose Embedding Models for Industry 4.0 Agents
summary:
In this work we focus on improving language models' understanding for asset
maintenance to guide the engineer's decisions and minimize asset downtime.
Given a set of tasks expressed in natural language for Industry 4.0 domain,
each associated with queries related to a specific asset, we want to recommend
relevant items and generalize to queries of similar assets. A task may involve
identifying relevant sensors given a query about an asset's failure mode.
  Our approach begins with gathering a qualitative, expert-vetted knowledge
base to construct nine asset-specific task datasets. To create more
contextually informed embeddings, we augment the input tasks using Large
Language Models (LLMs), providing concise descriptions of the entities involved
in the queries. This embedding model is then integrated with a Reasoning and
Acting agent (ReAct), which serves as a powerful tool for answering complex
user queries that require multi-step reasoning, planning, and knowledge
inference.
  Through ablation studies, we demonstrate that: (a) LLM query augmentation
improves the quality of embeddings, (b) Contrastive loss and other methods that
avoid in-batch negatives are superior for datasets with queries related to many
items, and (c) It is crucial to balance positive and negative in-batch samples.
After training and testing on our dataset, we observe a substantial
improvement: HIT@1 increases by +54.2%, MAP@100 by +50.1%, and NDCG@10 by
+54.7%, averaged across all tasks and models. Additionally, we empirically
demonstrate the model's planning and tool invocation capabilities when
answering complex questions related to industrial asset maintenance, showcasing
its effectiveness in supporting Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) in their
day-to-day operations.

AI.tldr: This paper enhances language models to improve engineering decisions in asset maintenance by utilizing LLMs for better query understanding and recommendation systems.
AI.motivation: To guide engineers in minimizing asset downtime through improved language model understanding of asset maintenance queries.
AI.method: The study gathers a qualitative, expert-vetted knowledge base to create nine asset-specific task datasets. It employs LLMs to augment tasks, generating contextually informed embeddings. These embeddings are integrated into a Reasoning and Acting agent (ReAct) for complex query resolution.
AI.result: The integration of LLM query augmentation significantly improves embedding quality and performance metrics such as HIT@1 (up by +54.2%), MAP@100 (up by +50.1%), and NDCG@10 (up by +54.7%). The model also demonstrates advanced planning and tool invocation capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The study showcases the effectiveness of using LLMs and a reasoning agent in supporting Subject Matter Experts in industrial asset maintenance tasks.
key_contributions: Development of an asset-specific task datasets for maintenance tasks
Integration of LLMs for enhancing embedding quality
Demonstration of advanced reasoning and planning capabilities in model application

title: Konooz: Multi-domain Multi-dialect Corpus for Named Entity Recognition
summary:
We introduce Konooz, a novel multi-dimensional corpus covering 16 Arabic
dialects across 10 domains, resulting in 160 distinct corpora. The corpus
comprises about 777k tokens, carefully collected and manually annotated with 21
entity types using both nested and flat annotation schemes - using the Wojood
guidelines. While Konooz is useful for various NLP tasks like domain adaptation
and transfer learning, this paper primarily focuses on benchmarking existing
Arabic Named Entity Recognition (NER) models, especially cross-domain and
cross-dialect model performance. Our benchmarking of four Arabic NER models
using Konooz reveals a significant drop in performance of up to 38% when
compared to the in-distribution data. Furthermore, we present an in-depth
analysis of domain and dialect divergence and the impact of resource scarcity.
We also measured the overlap between domains and dialects using the Maximum
Mean Discrepancy (MMD) metric, and illustrated why certain NER models perform
better on specific dialects and domains. Konooz is open-source and publicly
available at https://sina.birzeit.edu/wojood/#download

AI.tldr: Konooz is a multi-dimensional Arabic corpus aimed at enhancing NER model performance across various dialects and domains, revealing significant performance drops in certain conditions.
AI.motivation: To improve Arabic Named Entity Recognition (NER) through a comprehensive corpus that encapsulates dialect and domain variations.
AI.method: The paper introduces the Konooz corpus, which includes manual annotations of 21 entity types across 16 Arabic dialects and benchmarks four existing Arabic NER models using this corpus.
AI.result: Benchmarking revealed performance drops of up to 38% for NER models when applying them to cross-domain and cross-dialect scenarios compared to in-distribution data.
AI.conclusion: The study illustrates the challenges in NER model performance due to dialectal and domain divergences, emphasizing the importance of the Konooz corpus in addressing these issues.
key_contributions: Development of the Konooz corpus covering 16 Arabic dialects across diverse domains.
Benchmarking study of existing Arabic NER models highlighting performance drops in cross-domain and cross-dialect settings.
Analysis of resource scarcity effects on NER performance with a focus on the Maximum Mean Discrepancy metric.
AI.limitations: The performance analysis is limited to four specific NER models and may not represent all current models in Arabic NER.

title: OpenUnlearning: Accelerating LLM Unlearning via Unified Benchmarking of Methods and Metrics
summary:
Robust unlearning is crucial for safely deploying large language models
(LLMs) in environments where data privacy, model safety, and regulatory
compliance must be ensured. Yet the task is inherently challenging, partly due
to difficulties in reliably measuring whether unlearning has truly occurred.
Moreover, fragmentation in current methodologies and inconsistent evaluation
metrics hinder comparative analysis and reproducibility. To unify and
accelerate research efforts, we introduce OpenUnlearning, a standardized and
extensible framework designed explicitly for benchmarking both LLM unlearning
methods and metrics. OpenUnlearning integrates 9 unlearning algorithms and 16
diverse evaluations across 3 leading benchmarks (TOFU, MUSE, and WMDP) and also
enables analyses of forgetting behaviors across 450+ checkpoints we publicly
release. Leveraging OpenUnlearning, we propose a novel meta-evaluation
benchmark focused specifically on assessing the faithfulness and robustness of
evaluation metrics themselves. We also benchmark diverse unlearning methods and
provide a comparative analysis against an extensive evaluation suite. Overall,
we establish a clear, community-driven pathway toward rigorous development in
LLM unlearning research.

AI.tldr: OpenUnlearning is a framework for benchmarking unlearning in large language models, offering integrated algorithms and evaluation metrics.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of robust unlearning in large language models, focusing on data privacy and compliance.
AI.method: Introduction of OpenUnlearning, a standardized framework for benchmarking unlearning methods and metrics, integrating multiple algorithms and evaluations.
AI.result: The framework integrates 9 unlearning algorithms, 16 evaluations across 3 benchmarks, and analyzes forgetting behaviors across numerous checkpoints.
AI.conclusion: OpenUnlearning establishes a community pathway for enhanced rigor in LLM unlearning research.
key_contributions: Introduction of OpenUnlearning framework
Integration of multiple unlearning algorithms and evaluation metrics
Proposal of a meta-evaluation benchmark for metrics

title: Between Predictability and Randomness: Seeking Artistic Inspiration from AI Generative Models
comment:
Presented as a keynote at the 50th Linguistic Association of Canada
  and the United States (LACUS) conference in July 2024 and will be published
  in LACUS Forum 50
summary:
Artistic inspiration often emerges from language that is open to
interpretation. This paper explores the use of AI-generated poetic lines as
stimuli for creativity. Through analysis of two generative AI approaches--lines
generated by Long Short-Term Memory Variational Autoencoders (LSTM-VAE) and
complete poems by Large Language Models (LLMs)--I demonstrate that LSTM-VAE
lines achieve their evocative impact through a combination of resonant imagery
and productive indeterminacy. While LLMs produce technically accomplished
poetry with conventional patterns, LSTM-VAE lines can engage the artist through
semantic openness, unconventional combinations, and fragments that resist
closure. Through the composition of an original poem, where narrative emerged
organically through engagement with LSTM-VAE generated lines rather than
following a predetermined structure, I demonstrate how these characteristics
can serve as evocative starting points for authentic artistic expression.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the use of AI-generated poetic lines as creative stimuli, focusing on LSTM-VAE and LLM-generated content.
AI.motivation: To explore how AI-generated poetry can inspire creativity in artistic processes.
AI.method: Comparative analysis of poetry generated by LSTM-VAE and LLMs, along with the composition of an original poem based on LSTM-VAE lines.
AI.result: LSTM-VAE lines impact artists through resonant imagery and open semantics, whereas LLMs produce structurally conventional poetry.
AI.conclusion: AI-generated poetic lines can serve as novel starting points for authentic artistic expression, especially through LSTM-VAE's unique characteristics.
key_contributions: Demonstration of the evocative impact of LSTM-VAE poetry.
Comparison of LSTM-VAE and LLM-generated poetry.
Original poem composition using LSTM-VAE lines.

title: How Grounded is Wikipedia? A Study on Structured Evidential Support
summary:
Wikipedia is a critical resource for modern NLP, serving as a rich repository
of up-to-date and citation-backed information on a wide variety of subjects.
The reliability of Wikipedia -- its groundedness in its cited sources -- is
vital to this purpose. This work provides a quantitative analysis of the extent
to which Wikipedia *is* so grounded and of how readily grounding evidence may
be retrieved. To this end, we introduce PeopleProfiles -- a large-scale,
multi-level dataset of claim support annotations on Wikipedia articles of
notable people. We show that roughly 20% of claims in Wikipedia *lead* sections
are unsupported by the article body; roughly 27% of annotated claims in the
article *body* are unsupported by their (publicly accessible) cited sources;
and >80% of lead claims cannot be traced to these sources via annotated body
evidence. Further, we show that recovery of complex grounding evidence for
claims that *are* supported remains a challenge for standard retrieval methods.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the reliability of Wikipedia as a resource for NLP, introducing a dataset to evaluate claim support and demonstrating significant gaps in evidence backing claims.
AI.motivation: To assess Wikipedia's reliability as a resource for natural language processing by analyzing the grounding of claims in its articles.
AI.method: Introduction of PeopleProfiles, a large-scale dataset with annotations regarding claim support in Wikipedia articles about notable individuals, followed by a quantitative analysis of claim grounding.
AI.result: Approximately 20% of claims in Wikipedia lead sections are unsupported; around 27% of claims in article bodies lack support from cited sources; and over 80% of lead claims cannot be traced back to these sources.
AI.conclusion: The challenges in retrieving complex grounding evidence highlight the need for improved retrieval methods in NLP applications that utilize Wikipedia.
key_contributions: Introduction of the PeopleProfiles dataset for claim support annotations
Quantitative analysis revealing significant gaps in claim supportedness and retrieval
Highlighting challenges in grounding evidence for NLP applications using Wikipedia
AI.limitations: The study focuses exclusively on notable people, which may not represent all Wikipedia articles.

title: Synthetic Socratic Debates: Examining Persona Effects on Moral Decision and Persuasion Dynamics
summary:
As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used in morally sensitive
domains, it is crucial to understand how persona traits affect their moral
reasoning and persuasive behavior. We present the first large-scale study of
multi-dimensional persona effects in AI-AI debates over real-world moral
dilemmas. Using a 6-dimensional persona space (age, gender, country, class,
ideology, and personality), we simulate structured debates between AI agents
over 131 relationship-based cases. Our results show that personas affect
initial moral stances and debate outcomes, with political ideology and
personality traits exerting the strongest influence. Persuasive success varies
across traits, with liberal and open personalities reaching higher consensus
and win rates. While logit-based confidence grows during debates, emotional and
credibility-based appeals diminish, indicating more tempered argumentation over
time. These trends mirror findings from psychology and cultural studies,
reinforcing the need for persona-aware evaluation frameworks for AI moral
reasoning.

AI.tldr: This paper examines how AI personas influence moral reasoning and persuasive behavior through structured debates on moral dilemmas.
AI.motivation: To understand the impact of persona traits on moral reasoning and persuasive behavior in large language models, particularly in sensitive domains.
AI.method: A large-scale study simulating AI-AI debates using a 6-dimensional persona space (age, gender, country, class, ideology, personality) over 131 relationship-based cases.
AI.result: Personas notably affect initial moral stances and debate outcomes, with political ideology and personality traits showing the most influence. Liberal and open personalities yield higher consensus and win rates, while emotional appeals wane over the course of debates.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the necessity for persona-aware evaluation frameworks in AI moral reasoning, reflecting psychological and cultural insights.
key_contributions: First large-scale study of persona effects in AI debates
Identification of key persona traits affecting moral reasoning
Reinforcement of the need for persona-aware evaluation frameworks in AI
AI.limitations: The study is limited to AI agents and may not completely represent human moral reasoning dynamics.

title: Enhancing Clinical Models with Pseudo Data for De-identification
summary:
Many models are pretrained on redacted text for privacy reasons. Clinical
foundation models are often trained on de-identified text, which uses special
syntax (masked) text in place of protected health information. Even though
these models have increased in popularity, there has been little effort in
understanding the effects of training them on redacted text. In this work, we
pretrain several encoder-only models on a dataset that contains redacted text
and a version with replaced realistic pseudo text. We then fine-tuned models
for the protected health information de-identification task and show how our
methods significantly outperform previous baselines. The contributions of this
work include: a) our novel, and yet surprising findings with training
recommendations, b) redacted text replacements used to produce the pseudo
dataset, c) pretrained embeddings and fine-tuned task specific models, and d)
freely available pseudo training dataset generation and model source code used
in our experiments.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the effectiveness of training models on redacted text versus realistic pseudo text for de-identifying protected health information, achieving significant improvements in performance.
AI.motivation: To understand the impact of training clinical foundation models on redacted text, which is crucial for privacy in health informatics.
AI.method: Pretraining encoder-only models on datasets with redacted text and realistic pseudo text, followed by fine-tuning these models for the task of de-identifying protected health information.
AI.result: The proposed approach significantly outperforms previous baselines in the de-identification task.
AI.conclusion: Training recommendations and insights into using redacted text versus pseudo text are provided, along with accessible resources for further research.
key_contributions: Novel findings on training methods for de-identification tasks
Development of a dataset with redacted text replacements
Provision of pretrained embeddings and task-specific models
AI.limitations: Not specified

title: Flexible Realignment of Language Models
summary:
Realignment becomes necessary when a language model (LM) fails to meet
expected performance. We propose a flexible realignment framework that supports
quantitative control of alignment degree during training and inference. This
framework incorporates Training-time Realignment (TrRa), which efficiently
realigns the reference model by leveraging the controllable fusion of logits
from both the reference and already aligned models. For example, TrRa reduces
token usage by 54.63% on DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B without any performance
degradation, outperforming DeepScaleR-1.5B's 33.86%. To complement TrRa during
inference, we introduce a layer adapter that enables smooth Inference-time
Realignment (InRa). This adapter is initialized to perform an identity
transformation at the bottom layer and is inserted preceding the original
layers. During inference, input embeddings are simultaneously processed by the
adapter and the original layer, followed by the remaining layers, and then
controllably interpolated at the logit level. We upgraded
DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B from a slow-thinking model to one that supports
both fast and slow thinking, allowing flexible alignment control even during
inference. By encouraging deeper reasoning, it even surpassed its original
performance.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a flexible framework for realigning language models during training and inference through controllable fusion of logits and adaptive layer configurations, achieving significant reductions in token usage and improvements in reasoning.
AI.motivation: To enhance the performance of language models that fail to meet expected outcomes by implementing a flexible alignment framework.
AI.method: The framework introduces Training-time Realignment (TrRa) for efficient model realignment through logit fusion, and Inference-time Realignment (InRa), using a layer adapter to adaptively process inputs at inference.
AI.result: TrRa achieves a 54.63% reduction in token usage on DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-1.5B without performance loss, surpassing DeepScaleR-1.5B's 33.86%.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods enable fast and slow thinking capabilities in models like DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-7B, allowing for more profound reasoning and better overall performance.
key_contributions: Introduction of a flexible realignment framework for LMs.
Development of TrRa for efficient training-time realignment.
Implementation of InRa for dynamic inference alignment.

title: Rethinking Hate Speech Detection on Social Media: Can LLMs Replace Traditional Models?
summary:
Hate speech detection across contemporary social media presents unique
challenges due to linguistic diversity and the informal nature of online
discourse. These challenges are further amplified in settings involving
code-mixing, transliteration, and culturally nuanced expressions. While
fine-tuned transformer models, such as BERT, have become standard for this
task, we argue that recent large language models (LLMs) not only surpass them
but also redefine the landscape of hate speech detection more broadly. To
support this claim, we introduce IndoHateMix, a diverse, high-quality dataset
capturing Hindi-English code-mixing and transliteration in the Indian context,
providing a realistic benchmark to evaluate model robustness in complex
multilingual scenarios where existing NLP methods often struggle. Our extensive
experiments show that cutting-edge LLMs (such as LLaMA-3.1) consistently
outperform task-specific BERT-based models, even when fine-tuned on
significantly less data. With their superior generalization and adaptability,
LLMs offer a transformative approach to mitigating online hate in diverse
environments. This raises the question of whether future works should
prioritize developing specialized models or focus on curating richer and more
varied datasets to further enhance the effectiveness of LLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces IndoHateMix, a dataset aimed at improving hate speech detection in code-mixed Hindi-English contexts and demonstrates that large language models (LLMs) outperform traditional models.
AI.motivation: To address the unique challenges of hate speech detection in diverse and code-mixed online environments, particularly in social media.
AI.method: The authors introduce IndoHateMix, a dataset capturing Hindi-English code-mixing and conduct experiments comparing LLMs to BERT-based models in hate speech detection tasks.
AI.result: Experiments show that LLMs, like LLaMA-3.1, consistently outperform BERT-based models, even with less training data, demonstrating superior generalization.
AI.conclusion: LLMs may redefine hate speech detection strategies, suggesting a shift towards either developing specialized models or enriching datasets for better effectiveness.
key_contributions: Introduction of the IndoHateMix dataset for Hindi-English code-mixing.
Demonstration of superior performance of LLMs in hate speech detection tasks compared to BERT-based models.
Discussion on future directions for hate speech detection focusing on dataset quality.

title: Democratic or Authoritarian? Probing a New Dimension of Political Biases in Large Language Models
summary:
As Large Language Models (LLMs) become increasingly integrated into everyday
life and information ecosystems, concerns about their implicit biases continue
to persist. While prior work has primarily examined socio-demographic and
left--right political dimensions, little attention has been paid to how LLMs
align with broader geopolitical value systems, particularly the
democracy--authoritarianism spectrum. In this paper, we propose a novel
methodology to assess such alignment, combining (1) the F-scale, a psychometric
tool for measuring authoritarian tendencies, (2) FavScore, a newly introduced
metric for evaluating model favorability toward world leaders, and (3)
role-model probing to assess which figures are cited as general role-models by
LLMs. We find that LLMs generally favor democratic values and leaders, but
exhibit increases favorability toward authoritarian figures when prompted in
Mandarin. Further, models are found to often cite authoritarian figures as role
models, even outside explicit political contexts. These results shed light on
ways LLMs may reflect and potentially reinforce global political ideologies,
highlighting the importance of evaluating bias beyond conventional
socio-political axes. Our code is available at:
https://github.com/irenestrauss/Democratic-Authoritarian-Bias-LLMs

AI.tldr: This paper assesses the alignment of Large Language Models (LLMs) with geopolitical value systems, specifically the democracy-authoritarianism spectrum, revealing a general favor toward democratic values but also significant bias towards authoritarian figures in certain contexts.
AI.motivation: To explore how LLMs align with broader geopolitical value systems beyond traditional socio-demographic and political dimensions.
AI.method: The study utilizes a combination of the F-scale for authoritarian tendencies, FavScore for evaluating favorability toward world leaders, and role-model probing for assessing cited figures.
AI.result: Findings indicate that LLMs favor democratic values overall but show increased favorability towards authoritarian figures when prompted in Mandarin, often citing authoritarian figures as role models in various contexts.
AI.conclusion: Evaluating biases in LLMs should consider geopolitical ideologies, as they may reinforce and reflect political biases across different cultures.
key_contributions: Introduced a novel methodology to assess LLMs' alignment with geopolitical value systems.
Revealed that LLMs exhibit biases toward both democratic and authoritarian values based on language prompts.
Highlighted the necessity of evaluating biases beyond conventional socio-political axes.
AI.limitations: The study's scope may be limited by the languages and contexts in which the models were tested, potentially affecting generalizability.

title: Surprise Calibration for Better In-Context Learning
summary:
In-context learning (ICL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for task
adaptation in large language models (LLMs), where models infer underlying task
structures from a few demonstrations. However, ICL remains susceptible to
biases that arise from prior knowledge and contextual demonstrations, which can
degrade the performance of LLMs. Existing bias calibration methods typically
apply fixed class priors across all inputs, limiting their efficacy in dynamic
ICL settings where the context for each query differs. To address these
limitations, we adopt implicit sequential Bayesian inference as a framework for
interpreting ICL, identify "surprise" as an informative signal for class prior
shift, and introduce a novel method--Surprise Calibration (SC). SC leverages
the notion of surprise to capture the temporal dynamics of class priors,
providing a more adaptive and computationally efficient solution for in-context
learning. We empirically demonstrate the superiority of SC over existing bias
calibration techniques across a range of benchmark natural language processing
tasks.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Surprise Calibration (SC), a novel method for addressing biases in in-context learning of large language models by leveraging implicit sequential Bayesian inference and the concept of surprise for dynamic class prior adjustments.
AI.motivation: To improve the performance of in-context learning in large language models by addressing biases that arise from prior knowledge and contextual demonstrations.
AI.method: The authors propose Surprise Calibration (SC), using implicit sequential Bayesian inference to interpret in-context learning and identify 'surprise' as a signal for adjusting class priors dynamically.
AI.result: Surprise Calibration demonstrates significantly better performance in comparison to existing bias calibration techniques across various natural language processing benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Adopting surprise as a means to understand dynamic class priors offers a more adaptive and efficient approach to in-context learning in LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of Surprise Calibration (SC) for bias mitigation in ICL
Use of implicit sequential Bayesian inference in adapting class priors
Empirical validation of SC's superiority over existing methods

title: Medical Argument Mining: Exploitation of Scarce Data Using NLI Systems
comment: Accepted in the journal Procesamiento del Lenguaje Natural
summary:
This work presents an Argument Mining process that extracts argumentative
entities from clinical texts and identifies their relationships using token
classification and Natural Language Inference techniques. Compared to
straightforward methods like text classification, this methodology demonstrates
superior performance in data-scarce settings. By assessing the effectiveness of
these methods in identifying argumentative structures that support or refute
possible diagnoses, this research lays the groundwork for future tools that can
provide evidence-based justifications for machine-generated clinical
conclusions.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces an argument mining approach for extracting and analyzing argumentative entities in clinical texts, showing improved performance in low-data environments.
AI.motivation: To enhance understanding of clinical texts by extracting argumentative structures that either support or refute diagnoses, facilitating machine-generated clinical conclusions.
AI.method: Argument Mining leveraging token classification and Natural Language Inference techniques.
AI.result: The proposed methods achieve superior results over traditional text classification in data-scarce scenarios, effectively identifying argumentative relationships in clinical texts.
AI.conclusion: This study provides a foundation for developing tools that offer evidence-based justifications for machine-derived clinical conclusions.
key_contributions: Novel argument mining approach for clinical texts
Demonstrated superior performance in low-data scenarios
Framework for future clinical decision support tools

title: Transforming Chatbot Text: A Sequence-to-Sequence Approach
summary:
Due to advances in Large Language Models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, the boundary
between human-written text and AI-generated text has become blurred.
Nevertheless, recent work has demonstrated that it is possible to reliably
detect GPT-generated text. In this paper, we adopt a novel strategy to
adversarially transform GPT-generated text using sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq)
models, with the goal of making the text more human-like. We experiment with
the Seq2Seq models T5-small and BART which serve to modify GPT-generated
sentences to include linguistic, structural, and semantic components that may
be more typical of human-authored text. Experiments show that classification
models trained to distinguish GPT-generated text are significantly less
accurate when tested on text that has been modified by these Seq2Seq models.
However, after retraining classification models on data generated by our
Seq2Seq technique, the models are able to distinguish the transformed
GPT-generated text from human-generated text with high accuracy. This work adds
to the accumulating knowledge of text transformation as a tool for both attack
-- in the sense of defeating classification models -- and defense -- in the
sense of improved classifiers -- thereby advancing our understanding of
AI-generated text.

AI.tldr: This paper explores adversarial transformations of GPT-generated text using Seq2Seq models to enhance its human-like qualities, impacting its detectability by classifiers.
AI.motivation: The study addresses the challenge of distinguishing human-written text from AI-generated text, particularly in light of advancements in LLMs like ChatGPT.
AI.method: The authors employ sequence-to-sequence (Seq2Seq) models T5-small and BART to modify GPT-generated sentences to appear more like human-written text.
AI.result: Experiments show that classification models struggle to accurately identify GPT-generated texts modified by Seq2Seq, but retrained models achieve high accuracy in distinguishing them from authentic human texts.
AI.conclusion: The research enhances understanding of text transformations, highlighting their dual role in both undermining and improving text classification capabilities.
key_contributions: Introduced adversarial transformation for GPT-generated text.
Demonstrated the effectiveness of Seq2Seq models T5-small and BART in making AI text appear more human-like.
Provided insights into the implications of text transformation on text classification model performance.

title: QFFT, Question-Free Fine-Tuning for Adaptive Reasoning
summary:
Recent advancements in Long Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning models have
improved performance on complex tasks, but they suffer from overthinking, which
generates redundant reasoning steps, especially for simple questions. This
paper revisits the reasoning patterns of Long and Short CoT models, observing
that the Short CoT patterns offer concise reasoning efficiently, while the Long
CoT patterns excel in challenging scenarios where the Short CoT patterns
struggle. To enable models to leverage both patterns, we propose Question-Free
Fine-Tuning (QFFT), a fine-tuning approach that removes the input question
during training and learns exclusively from Long CoT responses. This approach
enables the model to adaptively employ both reasoning patterns: it prioritizes
the Short CoT patterns and activates the Long CoT patterns only when necessary.
Experiments on various mathematical datasets demonstrate that QFFT reduces
average response length by more than 50\%, while achieving performance
comparable to Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT). Additionally, QFFT exhibits
superior performance compared to SFT in noisy, out-of-domain, and low-resource
scenarios.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Question-Free Fine-Tuning (QFFT) to optimize reasoning patterns in Long Chain-of-Thought (CoT) models, enhancing efficiency while maintaining performance.
AI.motivation: To address the issue of overthinking in Long Chain-of-Thought models that leads to redundant reasoning, especially for simple questions.
AI.method: A fine-tuning approach called Question-Free Fine-Tuning (QFFT) eliminates the input question during training, focusing on learning from Long CoT responses to adaptively use both Short and Long CoT patterns.
AI.result: QFFT reduces the average response length by over 50% while maintaining performance comparable to Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), and demonstrating better results in challenging scenarios such as noisy and low-resource environments.
AI.conclusion: QFFT enhances reasoning efficiency by prioritizing Short CoT patterns while activating Long CoT patterns only when necessary, improving model adaptability and performance in various contexts.
key_contributions: Introduces Question-Free Fine-Tuning (QFFT) as a novel approach to model training.
Demonstrates significant reduction in response length without sacrificing performance.
Shows improved adaptability in noisy, out-of-domain, and low-resource scenarios.

title: ArgHiTZ at ArchEHR-QA 2025: A Two-Step Divide and Conquer Approach to Patient Question Answering for Top Factuality
comment:
This paper has been accepted for publication in Proceedings of the
  24th Workshop on Biomedical Natural Language Processing (BioNLP) at ACL 2025
summary:
This work presents three different approaches to address the ArchEHR-QA 2025
Shared Task on automated patient question answering. We introduce an end-to-end
prompt-based baseline and two two-step methods to divide the task, without
utilizing any external knowledge. Both two step approaches first extract
essential sentences from the clinical text, by prompt or similarity ranking,
and then generate the final answer from these notes. Results indicate that the
re-ranker based two-step system performs best, highlighting the importance of
selecting the right approach for each subtask. Our best run achieved an overall
score of 0.44, ranking 8th out of 30 on the leaderboard, securing the top
position in overall factuality.

AI.tldr: This paper discusses methods for automated patient question answering at the ArchEHR-QA 2025 Shared Task, highlighting the effectiveness of a re-ranker based two-step system.
AI.motivation: To provide effective automated answers to patient queries using clinical text without external knowledge.
AI.method: Introduced an end-to-end prompt-based baseline and two two-step methods for extracting essential sentences and generating answers.
AI.result: The re-ranker based two-step system outperformed others and ranked 8th out of 30, with the highest factuality score.
AI.conclusion: The results emphasize the significance of the chosen methodology for different subtasks in automated question answering.
key_contributions: Development of an end-to-end prompt-based baseline for patient Q&A.
Introduction of a re-ranker based two-step approach that outperformed standard methods.
Achievement of the highest factuality in answers among ranked submissions.

title: Assessing the Performance Gap Between Lexical and Semantic Models for Information Retrieval With Formulaic Legal Language
summary:
Legal passage retrieval is an important task that assists legal practitioners
in the time-intensive process of finding relevant precedents to support legal
arguments. This study investigates the task of retrieving legal passages or
paragraphs from decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU),
whose language is highly structured and formulaic, leading to repetitive
patterns. Understanding when lexical or semantic models are more effective at
handling the repetitive nature of legal language is key to developing retrieval
systems that are more accurate, efficient, and transparent for specific legal
domains. To this end, we explore when this routinized legal language is better
suited for retrieval using methods that rely on lexical and statistical
features, such as BM25, or dense retrieval models trained to capture semantic
and contextual information. A qualitative and quantitative analysis with three
complementary metrics shows that both lexical and dense models perform well in
scenarios with more repetitive usage of language, whereas BM25 performs better
than the dense models in more nuanced scenarios where repetition and
verbatim~quotes are less prevalent and in longer queries. Our experiments also
show that BM25 is a strong baseline, surpassing off-the-shelf dense models in 4
out of 7 performance metrics. However, fine-tuning a dense model on
domain-specific data led to improved performance, surpassing BM25 in most
metrics, and we analyze the effect of the amount of data used in fine-tuning on
the model's performance and temporal robustness. The code, dataset and appendix
related to this work are available on:
https://github.com/larimo/lexsem-legal-ir.

AI.tldr: This study investigates legal passage retrieval from Court of Justice of the European Union decisions, examining the effectiveness of lexical vs. dense retrieval models in various scenarios of legal language repetition.
AI.motivation: To develop more accurate and efficient legal retrieval systems by understanding the effectiveness of different retrieval methods in handling repetitive legal language.
AI.method: Qualitative and quantitative analysis using metrics to compare the performance of lexical models (like BM25) and dense retrieval models on legal language.
AI.result: Lexical and dense models perform well on repetitive language scenarios; BM25 outperforms dense models in nuanced conditions. Fine-tuning dense models on domain-specific data can improve performance significantly.
AI.conclusion: BM25 is a strong baseline but fine-tuning dense models can surpass it in many performance metrics, demonstrating the importance of domain-specific training data.
key_contributions: Comparison of retrieval methods for legal language
Insight into the performance of BM25 versus dense models
Analysis of fine-tuning effects on retrieval accuracy
AI.limitations: Limited to legal language and decisions from the CJEU; results may vary in other legal contexts.

title: JEBS: A Fine-grained Biomedical Lexical Simplification Task
comment:
13 pages, 2 figures, to be published in Proceedings of the 63rd
  Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
summary:
Online medical literature has made health information more available than
ever, however, the barrier of complex medical jargon prevents the general
public from understanding it. Though parallel and comparable corpora for
Biomedical Text Simplification have been introduced, these conflate the many
syntactic and lexical operations involved in simplification. To enable more
targeted development and evaluation, we present a fine-grained lexical
simplification task and dataset, Jargon Explanations for Biomedical
Simplification (JEBS, https://github.com/bill-from-ri/JEBS-data ). The JEBS
task involves identifying complex terms, classifying how to replace them, and
generating replacement text. The JEBS dataset contains 21,595 replacements for
10,314 terms across 400 biomedical abstracts and their manually simplified
versions. Additionally, we provide baseline results for a variety of rule-based
and transformer-based systems for the three sub-tasks. The JEBS task, data, and
baseline results pave the way for development and rigorous evaluation of
systems for replacing or explaining complex biomedical terms.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the Jargon Explanations for Biomedical Simplification (JEBS) dataset, aimed at facilitating the simplification of complex biomedical terminology.
AI.motivation: The increasing availability of online medical literature is hindered by complex jargon that is difficult for the general public to understand.
AI.method: The study presents a fine-grained lexical simplification task that involves identifying complex terms, classifying their replacements, and generating simplified text. It introduces the JEBS dataset, which includes 21,595 replacements for 10,314 terms derived from 400 biomedical abstracts and their simplified versions.
AI.result: Baseline results are provided for various rule-based and transformer-based systems on the JEBS dataset, highlighting effectiveness in the three sub-tasks of simplification.
AI.conclusion: The JEBS dataset and task support targeted development and evaluation of systems aimed at simplifying biomedical text for broader accessibility.
key_contributions: Introduction of the JEBS dataset for lexical simplification in biomedical texts.
Fine-grained task definition facilitating targeted research in text simplification.
Baseline performance metrics for rule-based and transformer-based models.

title: SciDA: Scientific Dynamic Assessor of LLMs
summary:
Advancement in Large Language Models (LLMs) reasoning capabilities enables
them to solve scientific problems with enhanced efficacy. Thereby, a
high-quality benchmark for comprehensive and appropriate assessment holds
significance, while existing ones either confront the risk of data
contamination or lack involved disciplines. To be specific, due to the data
source overlap of LLMs training and static benchmark, the keys or number
pattern of answers inadvertently memorized (i.e. data contamination), leading
to systematic overestimation of their reasoning capabilities, especially
numerical reasoning. We propose SciDA, a multidisciplinary benchmark that
consists exclusively of over 1k Olympic-level numerical computation problems,
allowing randomized numerical initializations for each inference round to avoid
reliance on fixed numerical patterns. We conduct a series of experiments with
both closed-source and open-source top-performing LLMs, and it is observed that
the performance of LLMs drop significantly under random numerical
initialization. Thus, we provide truthful and unbiased assessments of the
numerical reasoning capabilities of LLMs. The data is available at
https://huggingface.co/datasets/m-a-p/SciDA

AI.tldr: The paper introduces SciDA, a multidisciplinary benchmark designed to assess the numerical reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) using randomized numerical initialization.
AI.motivation: The need for a high-quality benchmark to accurately evaluate LLMs' reasoning capabilities without data contamination and proper representation of diverse disciplines.
AI.method: The authors created SciDA, which consists of over 1,000 Olympic-level numerical computation problems with the ability to randomize numerical values for each inference to prevent memorization.
AI.result: Experimental results show that the performance of LLMs significantly decreases when subjected to randomized numerical initialization, indicating the limitations of their numerical reasoning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: SciDA offers an unbiased assessment tool that highlights the actual reasoning capabilities of LLMs, particularly in numerical contexts, and addresses data contamination issues present in existing benchmarks.
key_contributions: Introduction of a new benchmark (SciDA) specifically for evaluating numerical reasoning in LLMs.
Utilization of randomized numerical initializations to combat data contamination.
Large-scale evaluation with both closed-source and open-source LLMs.

title: PersonaFeedback: A Large-scale Human-annotated Benchmark For Personalization
summary:
With the rapid improvement in the general capabilities of LLMs, LLM
personalization, i.e., how to build LLM systems that can generate personalized
responses or services that are tailored to distinct user personas, has become
an increasingly important research and engineering problem. However, unlike
many new challenging benchmarks being released for evaluating the
general/reasoning capabilities, the lack of high-quality benchmarks for
evaluating LLM personalization greatly hinders progress in this field. To
address this, we introduce PersonaFeedback, a new benchmark that directly
evaluates LLMs' ability to provide personalized responses given pre-defined
user personas and queries. Unlike existing benchmarks that require models to
infer implicit user personas from historical interactions, PersonaFeedback
decouples persona inference from personalization, focusing on evaluating the
model's ability to generate responses tailored to explicit personas.
PersonaFeedback consists of 8298 human-annotated test cases, which are
categorized into easy, medium, and hard tiers based on the contextual
complexity of the user personas and the difficulty in distinguishing subtle
differences between two personalized responses. We conduct comprehensive
evaluations across a wide range of models. The empirical results reveal that
even state-of-the-art LLMs that can solve complex real-world reasoning tasks
could fall short on the hard tier of PersonaFeedback where even human
evaluators may find the distinctions challenging. Furthermore, we conduct an
in-depth analysis of failure modes across various types of systems,
demonstrating that the current retrieval-augmented framework should not be seen
as a de facto solution for personalization tasks. All benchmark data,
annotation protocols, and the evaluation pipeline will be publicly available to
facilitate future research on LLM personalization.

AI.tldr: Introducing PersonaFeedback, a benchmark for evaluating LLM personalization based on distinct user personas, with a focus on tailored responses.
AI.motivation: The rapid improvement in LLM capabilities necessitates effective evaluation benchmarks for LLM personalization to overcome the lack of such resources and advance research in the field.
AI.method: PersonaFeedback consists of 8298 human-annotated test cases categorized into easy, medium, and hard tiers, focusing on the model's ability to generate personalized responses based on predefined user personas.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show state-of-the-art LLMs struggle with the hard tier of PersonaFeedback, revealing limitations in their personalization capabilities even when they excel at complex reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: The benchmark and accompanying resources aim to facilitate further research in LLM personalization by providing a standardized evaluation framework.
key_contributions: Introduction of PersonaFeedback benchmark for LLM personalization
Decoupled persona inference from personalization in evaluations
Comprehensive evaluations across various models with publicly available data and protocols
AI.limitations: Current retrieval-augmented frameworks are insufficient for addressing personalization tasks effectively.

title: SoundMind: RL-Incentivized Logic Reasoning for Audio-Language Models
summary:
While large language models have shown reasoning capabilities, their
application to the audio modality, particularly in large audio-language models
(ALMs), remains significantly underdeveloped. Addressing this gap requires a
systematic approach, involving a capable base model, high-quality
reasoning-oriented audio data, and effective training algorithms. In this
study, we present a comprehensive solution: we introduce the Audio Logical
Reasoning (ALR) dataset, consisting of 6,446 text-audio annotated samples
specifically designed for complex reasoning tasks. Building on this resource,
we propose SoundMind, a rule-based reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm
tailored to endow ALMs with deep bimodal reasoning abilities. By training
Qwen2.5-Omni-7B on the ALR dataset using SoundMind, our approach achieves
state-of-the-art performance in audio logical reasoning. This work highlights
the impact of combining high-quality, reasoning-focused datasets with
specialized RL techniques, advancing the frontier of auditory intelligence in
language models. Our code and the proposed dataset are available at
https://github.com/xid32/SoundMind.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the Audio Logical Reasoning (ALR) dataset and the SoundMind reinforcement learning algorithm to enhance audio-language models' reasoning capabilities.
AI.motivation: The aim is to improve the application of large language models in audio modalities, which is currently lacking in complex reasoning capabilities.
AI.method: We created the ALR dataset with 6,446 text-audio samples and developed the SoundMind rule-based RL algorithm to train the Qwen2.5-Omni-7B model.
AI.result: Our method achieved state-of-the-art performance in audio logical reasoning tasks, demonstrating the effectiveness of combining high-quality datasets and specialized training techniques.
AI.conclusion: The integration of reasoning-focused datasets with reinforcement learning significantly advances auditory intelligence in language models.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Audio Logical Reasoning (ALR) dataset
Development of SoundMind, a rule-based RL algorithm
Achieved state-of-the-art performance in audio logical reasoning

title: CliniDial: A Naturally Occurring Multimodal Dialogue Dataset for Team Reflection in Action During Clinical Operation
summary:
In clinical operations, teamwork can be the crucial factor that determines
the final outcome. Prior studies have shown that sufficient collaboration is
the key factor that determines the outcome of an operation. To understand how
the team practices teamwork during the operation, we collected CliniDial from
simulations of medical operations. CliniDial includes the audio data and its
transcriptions, the simulated physiology signals of the patient manikins, and
how the team operates from two camera angles. We annotate behavior codes
following an existing framework to understand the teamwork process for
CliniDial. We pinpoint three main characteristics of our dataset, including its
label imbalances, rich and natural interactions, and multiple modalities, and
conduct experiments to test existing LLMs' capabilities on handling data with
these characteristics. Experimental results show that CliniDial poses
significant challenges to the existing models, inviting future effort on
developing methods that can deal with real-world clinical data. We open-source
the codebase at https://github.com/MichiganNLP/CliniDial

AI.tldr: The study introduces CliniDial, a dataset for analyzing teamwork in clinical operations through audio, physiology signals, and video data, revealing challenges for existing LLMs in handling such complex data.
